number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												NOTE: I have been playing this game for some years now. And am judging based off my own opinion and experiences.As said above, I have been playing since nearly the start of this game, with little to no complaints. Though Neverwinter is now long past any similarity to what it used to be, it can still be an enjoyable game with lots of story and lore. Though the community takes a little to get used to, and work with. For the content they have added and thus also taken away, I would say that I could not agree with a lot of their actions on this as it has taken away a lot of the casual play and enjoyment away from what the game once had. Though it is free to play, it does have heavy pay to play elements to it as well, which is highly evident in PvP. The new class changeups have also played against what used to be an accepted balanced system. The new mod to be released will add in Strongholds for individual guilds to take and/or fight over in PvP battles. This will indeed give a new reason to be a part of a good and trusted guild, which many can be found here.I will say that if you have friends or plan to make some Neverwinter can be a good place for that. Personally, I have made many online friends here who I still know a couple of years down the road. I give Neverwinter, my old home away from home, a thumbs up as it is a good game to play for free to play.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I've played this game for about 20 hours now. I leveled a Half-Elf ranger from level 1-40, and I can't say I recommend this game right now. In a lot of ways, NW falls short of the WoW watermark, and that's a shame, because I was hoping it would be a good successor to DDO and WoW as an MMO great. Let me say that on my SLI GTX 760s I did not experience any stutter. The game didn't even access more than 30% of these cards during play, which makes me think this could be played on a tablet if someone wanted to. Which is good if you don't have a system with great specs. Secondly, the game's visuals are only okay by 2010-2011 standards. This was released in 2013, and in 2016, it looks bad. Graphics are very flat with no shadows, no specular highlights, and no volumetric fog at all. Player meshes look like they were designed for cell phone support. Overall, visually, this is the worst MMO I've played in a great while.But that wouldn't be a reason that I wouldn't recommend it, that comes in with the gameplay, and its annoyances start to become more apparent the longer you play and come into your class. As a ranger specializing in archery, I progressed through the game, but found myself fighting with the mechanics of the game more than the monsters. Either a mob would path behind a wall and I'd lose my shot on them, or the skill that I chose to control aggro of mobs just wasn't all that good. One of the rooting shots in the Hunter tree roots for about 1 second, even on rank 3/4...(You don't gain access to the 4th tier of abilities until level 70).But the main reason why I won't be playing this too much longer is because of the game's broken companion AI. It's terrible. You can't set your pet to aggressive, passive, or neutral. And that makes it impossible to use the companion as a tank. On average, my companion was able to pull aggro on 2/5 of every mob set I went into. That's simply not good enough. You can't even tell the pet to attack before you shoot your bow, so you have basically no control over aggro whatsoever. With my reduced threat perk maxed, I always wound up with enemies charging at me, and running out of stamina too quickly.There were times when I would trigger combat intentionally, wait for the companion to charge in and get some hits, then I would retreat to max bow range only to have the companion disengage for no reason and come running to me. I don't get it. This would happen in crypt-sized dungeons as well as outdoor maps.In addition, around level 40, the game starts setting you up with obvious AMBUSH chokepoints on the map, which antagonize your abilities to no end. Hunter/Archer skills are about keeping an enemy at range, and when you have to walk onto a trigger point where 10 enemies pop in surrounding you on all sides at point blank range, it makes everything in your action bar kind of pointless.Bottom line, if you're going to do this, don't play a ranged class unless you have a friend dedicated to going through the quests with you. It's pointless, and I just wasted 20 hours figuring that out. Until they fix these issues, I can't recommend Neverwinter.

number of helpful: 43 of 77 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												This review is currently in progress and should only be taken as a first impression of the game.Graphics: 7Gritty and decently realistic, but textures are unusually low quality and character models are a bit chunky.Sound: 7Average sound, not bad, not good.  Has decent voice overs.Gameplay: 5Combat similair to Tera online except you can't move while attacking, only dodge moves.  It suffers the same problem as Tera online that it's just hiding the targeting from you, but still auto targets whichever monster is closest to your cursor when you attack.  This is extremly obvious on a ranger where the split arrow move is very difficult to aim as you can't aim between enemies to hit them both, when you right click your camera auto targets one of the enemies making the attack less accurate.Like every other MMO, it follows the questing format that we've all grown bored of.Impression: 3As an MMO it doesn't break any new ground that hasn't already been broken by Tera online.  The graphics are lower than some newer MMO's, the combat is slower, and the quests are still boring.  The game makes a vague attempt to play to neverwinter lore, but then falls appart with pre-made canned characters removing the ability to apply dungeons and dragons like upgrades.  If you were hoping to roll your own character, play Dungeons and Dragons online instead which does a much better job of letting you roll play your own character.Value: ?Unknown, haven't played long enough.Summary (In progress):I see no reason for this game to exist, the same formula has been used countless times before.  If your in this for the social aspect, play the game the rest of your friends are playing.  If your looking for D&D style roll playing, play D&D Online.  If your looking for active combat, play Tera online or Vindictus.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Although all the cons, I'm still recommending this game. It is simply fun. If you do not have high expectations, just wish to spend some time it is your game.Pros: - Well it is fun. The quests are narrated, and have real stories. Also you can find lots of lore objects to know more about the world.- Looks nice.- Almost all of the tools / interfaces are reachable from Browser.- Have a minigame with dice-rolling, from browser, if you have 5-10 mins during the day. The minigame can yield in useful items. (I have not told it will be quick, as the Tier6 dungeons are really hard - like collect 18 shield from 8 dice...)- Have some connections with the original Neverwinter games.Cons:- It is not D&D.- Still bugging after almost 1 year, eg: many times the daily quests cannot be completed.- Lagging, in dungeons the latency usually fine, but around peak hours it is (or at least feels like) more than a second, and with the dodging system, it is sometimes lethal.- Graphics of the game is nice, but clattering. It would really need some optimalization- The PvE part is fun, till lv 55 and after it became hard, and turning to a pay to win game.- The PVP part is still under development, some pvp is available, but the single map became boring after a while.- Items has variety of looks, although the same item looks the same on all of the races. At least as dwarf, I have not seen any difference from sun elf, or from humans.- To gather the "real" money, the astral diamond is really slow, and painful. (daily quest gives 3k - x4 as there are 4 quests, with 1-1 hour to complete-, while 300k is needed for the simplest upgrade - horse, companion, ...).- It may be annoys you, but the game constantly downloading in the background.Actually the Zen / AD system (astral diamond) is confusing to be bad or good. It is the same as all Perfect World games.- You can buy Zen. It is an universal curency within PW games. If you transfer it to NW, it can be traded for AD in the exchange, or use it to buy items directly from Zen market. As the game is free to play and the servers has to be maintened, this will generate the income they are loosing with removing the monthly fee.- It is mentioned that everything can be collected just with play without pay. Right. To collect 1 purple artisan resource, you need 4 blue, 1 blue is 4 green, 1 green is 4 white(lv3), 1 white (lv3) is 4 white (lv2), 1 white (lv2) is 4 white (lv1), each trainings are 18 hours (offline time also counts). It is 1365 cycle x 18 hours, which is ~1000 days. At lv 60, you possibly have 5-6 slots opened already, so it is ~200 days.  And you will need 9 as you have a total 9 slots for professions. Or you can buy profession pack with a chance of green/blue/purple resource for Zen or for AD from AH (green 250k, blue 1mill, purple 4 mill AD).- Also myths on the internet are saying, with proper trading you can gather 300k AD / day, and there are several guides available on the internet how, but for it you have to be professional stock handler (Zen / AD exchange), or tradesman constantly monitoring the offers and needs on the AH.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												I've changed this review several times. The game gets good, the game gets bad, and then it gets mediocre again.But this time they can't bring me back, and I know for a fact that they have lost many other loyal fans.With the addition of Module 6, Elemental Evil, came the realization that the developers behind this game care nothing for it, and only care to fill Cryptic's wallets.They do not develop the game. They develop a business, and a shoddy one at that.With this most recent module came a level cap increase. This increase was very poorly integrated, both from a chronological standpoint as well as a financial standpoint. It was released only a few months after the "Rise of Tiamat" campaign, which introduced the game's first set of Legendary "Artifact" weapons and armor. These were made obsolete by the raise in level cap. Also integrated were several new maps, which proved equally as useless and buggy. They were essentially re-lit versions of maps from old campaigns. Mind you, Module 6 was postponed a whole month from it's original date; for what? Exceedingly subpar, untested content.For several months now, the developers have been growing increasingly greedy; discovering all the ways they can obtain peoples' money. Mounts, bags, respecs, rerolls, race changes, companions, a number of sneaky maneuvers that get you to believe "Oh, it's just a few dollars here and there, for convenience." They aren't convenient. They are Cryptic's. Whatever you purchase with your money is still THEIRS. They can change the parameters of what you've puchased at any time. That is to say, they can remove items from packs, change them from being bound to account to being bind on equip or bind on pickup, and not even change the item's description in doing so. And you can do nothing about it.They fired their old dev after Mod 6's release, hired a new one, and he immediately promised to "fix the game." He hardly acknowledged many of the most prominant complaints, and in his first hotpatch made the purchasable bags "Bind on Equip" from "Bound to Account."A community moderator from their forums gave me an interesting quote to work with:"This has been said repeatedly, ad infinitum and ad nauseam: Read and abide by the Rules of Conduct. Then you won't have to worry about being moderated--and no, you don't get to interpret them to your liking.This isn't your soapbox. This isn't your crap can. You are, in a manner of speaking, in Cryptic's house. The rules of Conduct are the house rules. You wouldn't go into someone else's house and talk a bunch of crud about their house and how they run it, and not expect to be abruptly shown the door, no? Then don't expect to be able to do it here.There is a way to go about showing concern and dissatisfaction besides being insulting, condescending, rude, or demeaning. We don't expect everything to be sunshine and rainbows but there is a constructive and civilized way to go about it."-lewstelamon01, Community ModeratorThis quote pretty much shows you how much of a catch-22 their customer support is. There are constructive ways of going about it, but what is "constructive" is purely based on their judgement alone. I have seen many a support thread shut down, by this moderator and others, because it was "unconstructive."They weed through, delete the flack, and make sure to remove anything remotely within the parameters of their "Moderator handbook" so that the forums look clean and pretty to any new onlooker that might be seaching for an opinion on the game.Hopelessly corrupt and nearing a fatal blow, is how I would describe Neverwinter Online. Don't let them see a penny of your money unless you want it to slip into the abyss.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I first picked this game up when it was released. My initial impression was good. A Free to Play that seemed to allow players to advance without spending real money, albeit  a bit slower than paying players, is acceptable. The combat system is not quite what I was expecting from a D&D title (cooldown based abilities all around), but it is still a LOT of fun. Very easy, quick controls that respond well, as long as the server is not lagging (which, unfortunately, happens a LOT). But I still played it, and had a lot of fun doing so. I spent a little money on it, just so I could open some of those lockboxes, and I did manage to get an epic sword and cloak out of them. This was a couple of years ago, though, before the changes that recently hit. Since then, they have taken this game from a Free-to-Play to an all out money grab. It has gone from Free-to-Play, to Pay-to-Win. -AD rewards have been nerfed. No way to acquire the currency needed to buy things from the auction house unless you buy something from the Zen market first. -The zone dungeons are broken (literally removed from the game, for reasons I will speculate on later). -We now have at least 3 types of those infernal, blasted, annoying, inventory-slot-robbing lockboxes that can only be opened with a key that can only be acquired through the Zen market. I have only seen 3 types; there are likely more, and they drop CONSTANTLY. You WILL get them, even when you don't want them. There are constant system messages pasting across the screen, stating things like,"So-and-so just got an epic whats-it-ma-thingy-with-flames-flying-from-its-rump from a Rusted, drops-all-the-time, yet somehow still shows EPIC rarity lockbox of money grabbing." -Loot drops, which were never all that great, are now an abysmal joke. I consistently see the same 2 or 3 pieces of armor dropping in every single zone.-Quest rewards are a waste, if not an outright insult. Remember when I said the dungeons were removed? Yeah, those used to be the only source of decent gear in the game that didn't require you to open your wallet. They're gone now, but the devs left the quest links and markers in place. I saw all these changes, and I decided to conduct an experiment. I bought $50.00 worth of Zen and bought as many keys as I could. I think I ended up with thirty of them, making each one cost about $1.60. I had some Zen left over, but not enough to buy anything without coughing up more real money (seriously, do ALL of these games have pricing schemes that make it impossible to take your "currency" balance to zero?). Anyway, I opened 30 of those damnable lock boxes, and got CRAP. A handful of epic enchantments. A couple of blue craftsmen. Oh, and a 5th character slot for buying stuff on the Zen market. 50 bucks got me NOTHING worth mentioning. No epic gear, like it was in the early days. No new mounts. Just a bunch of enchantments, runestones, and a modest amount of astral diamonds. Pathetic. I could go on, but I won't. I'll just say that this game was, when it launched, much less greedy. Players who spent a few bucks would be rewarded with epic gear that levelled with their character, or a cool mount. Not any more. Neverwinter is now such an obvious wallet leech that the very first screen it gives you upon logging in is the Zen market. Draw your own conclusions from that.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Stay far away from this game, if you're new to it. Your wallet (and sanity) will thank me later.Many MMORPGs fail to consider their new blood, but this is easily one of the most egregious offenders you can find on Steam as a whole. It's a blight on gaming in general, an abject lesson in taking a once-great title and driving it straight into the ground over money. There's no balance of time versus money. You will pay up on this one, or you won't be competitive.The PvE content is only truly fun up till 60 (when they introduce the horrible Mod 6 content -- and it just gets worse from there on in terms of agonisingly boring grinding), and PvP is for masochists only. Mobs will regularly one or two shot you in epic dungeons, and established players are invincible in the battlegrounds... assuming you can find a PvP match at all, with the game's lengthy queues. This developer has chased their players away, and for good reason.

												I played this game years ago with a friend. I never liked the combat system, due to the way animations freeze your character in place, making the combat actually feel much less smooth than 'non-action' MMOs like WoW or similar. But playing with a friend it might have been fun enough, except it was so repetitive. We got to like the second area or something and the whole place was just groups of the same 5 orcs over and over, with the occasional ogre. Every quest was just some variation on "fight/kill the orcs". It was one of the most astonishingly boring and grindy experiences I have had in an MMO, and we both quit in frustration. It's got to be pretty bad if playing with a friend can't save it.By all accounts the game is even worse now than it was back then, so I would definitely stay steer clear.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												After playing my heart out of Neverwinter Nights 2 in my teen years, I came upon this game with nostalgia induced passion. Only to realize this is the age of Pay-to-Win gaming. A factor I found that hurt the core of the games that utilized this. Neverwinter Nights 2 may have been an old game, and I still play it now, but I cannot bring myself to hit the "thumbs up" on this game. I have never liked an RPG based game that did not enforce actual Roleplaying, utilized Pay-to-Win gaming, and whose active community was unwelcoming.I don't mean to say this is a bad game, it's got a few great features, such as:- Graphical abilities- Great Camera Angling- The ability to actually jump.- Utilizes D&D 4.0 guidelines- Interesting progression rates- Great HUD- Free to playBut here were the exact areas I felt hurt the actual gameplay:- Pay-to-Win- Non-enforced RolePlay in a RolePlaying Game & Server (players talking OOC all the time)- Unwelcoming community- Leveling up granted no satisfaction in creating your character- In-ability to crossclassThough personally I would rather play D&D 3.5

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Used to be fun.  Ignore my hrs recorded here on Steam as I usually play via ARC and only use this to play the game when ARC is going crazy and won't let me log in. It used to have a free to play model and in some ways, it still is.  However, they  (as of this writing) have sneakily reinserted a subscription perk called a VIP program that makes it pay to win as the perks listed definitely brings a major advantage against most non-subs.  Also, as of this writing, there's some tomfoolery going on during high level dungeons crawls on pugs that gets you kicked out via teammates that want the loot for themselves or for their friends that weren't even in the group.  I started playing around February of 2015 and got almost all of my toons of every class and race not hidden behind a pay wall to max level, but the grind for gear on dungeons for the newly max level character almost stops due to other players kicking you out of the group for the abovementioned reason in regards to loot.   After experiencing it more than once soured my overall experience of the game.     Pros: fun levelling, impressive graphics, some of the quests are downright hilarious in terms of story/spoken dialogue.Cons: See my rant above.Conclusion:  If you can stand the cons, then you'll enjoy the game.   It could have been a WOW killer... unfortunately, that potential got wasted.

												I have hundreds of hours into playing this game.  I have enjoyed playing it greatly.  It is so far my all time favorite MMO.  No fluff no hype....it is FUN!As far as those who gripe about the "Pay to Win" minomer, no game this good is without cost to make and continue improving.  The game offers variety and challenge.  There is always something new to explore.  On any Free to Play game, a customer would have to get something for their money or who would ever pay at all?  With that said, I can recommend you try it for free see what it is about then decide. I can also recommend you do some reading about the class types and how to build a strong player character. There's alot of variety possible.  Taking on the challenge of this game and building a strong character is very rewarding.9.6/10 for me.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												This game should be somewhat interesting to DnD fans - if you don't count yourself one, I would warn you to stay away from this game.Leveling your first character from lvl 1 to lvl 60 is kinda fun - exploring Neverwinter and it's surroundings, visiting Underdark, dealing with Spellplague, bla-bla-bla - only if you don't mind underpopulated locations. Seriously, expect to see some really large zones that have only "kill 10 mobs" quest.Everything changes drastically when you're hitting lvl 60 - after that it's just one big grind fest.You get some new zones to grind daily quests, which reward with providing access to new daily quests, which reward you with some gear that allows you grind these daily quests more efficiently. Endgame content is a myth - 2 PvP arenas and, like, 4-5 dungeons designed for 5 ppl max.'Elemental Evil' addon should've patched things up - players got tired of daily quests, everyone wanted to see some new epic content, etc.So developers really listened to the community - now you have one raid instance, that's designed for level 70 characters. But, yeah, it's available only after you've spent several dozen hours - you get it - on your most favorite daily quests.Not to mention that reaching lvl 70 is a one big DAILY QUEST GRIND from lvl 60.Yeah, and to add an insult to injury - this game features something like 200 or 250 different currency types, so I guess we can label the game as new-player-friendly.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Okay. This is a pretty standard copy/paste mmorpg. I initially played when it first came out, I only played a few hours, got sick of it's genericness and stopped. Came back figuring I was a bit too harsh to quit so early in the game (I wasn't) and here we go.Dated Graphics with low poly models. But the game is an unoptimised waste of system resources. If your system is fine with it, like mine was until I entered town the reason is -> you'll find that whenever other players are around you your start to actually download data that you should already have on your system in order to see those players, such as models and textures. Basically - the game only installs monster models and npc data on your system to keep the download short. After that whenever you walk around the game world and see players wearing gear you don't have, the game downloads it automatically whilst you play. So you'll be stuttering like a mother♥♥♥♥ing slovenian on a computato for a good hour.Music isn't memorable, few hours after playing you could seriously wander if it had any music at all. Gameplay, rather bland and grindy, just spamming left click.Animations, clunky, enemies like to glide along faster than their animations.Tutorial/Introduction - Unimaginative garbage. You wash up on shore with no gear, then loot boxes to get newb gear, talking to people along the beach. Literally the exact same introduction as path of exile and age of conan. Then you talk to some people at a camp and get a quest (am I playing path of exile?) then you go and kill some undead (okay, what the ♥♥♥♥, this IS path of exile) Pretty standard Press "button" to interact on objects, interact on more objects, talk to people - by interacting on them with button. After that you fight more undead, because hey, they didn't use the same model and monsters enough in the lame♥♥♥♥♥introduction that now they're sending you to a crypt with totally unrelated undead who just happen to be there. Then you go to some slums, because trouble starts at home and fight some guys. Time to go to the sewers and fight the rat men and solve incredibly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥puzzles! This turned from a review to a splurge of hate, so I'm stopping it here. This is a generic piece of♥♥♥♥♥ I literally feel like I've been ripped off and I didn't spend any money, just time. Time I could've spent playing a better game.Oh did I mention that a majority of the game is instanced based, y'know dungeons. You don't even get to see other people in your quests, it's like playing a single player game with random people standing around blocking NPCs. (Oh yea, if there are too many people around an npc, good luck interacting with them, you'll be bringing up player menus with the same button!)

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19
												This game is really fun. It has pretty much all the things you'd want from an MMO, with the added advantage of really neat animations and a more actiony gameplay. The fact it's set in forgotten realms, with stories and dialogue at some parts written by RA Salvatore himself, is icing on the cake.The game is very grindy, but it's a good kind of grind, with a point to it. You work towards boons (permenant buffs) in every campaign that contribute well to the power of your character. The best part is on your first character it doesn't really feel too grindy at all. Subsequent characters kinda get a *grooooan* but at the same time, you're still working towards something. I really like the grindy aspect, personally. This is not a game you will play for a few weeks then sit in town crying that you have nothing to do. This is an MMO with a real investment :)I have played every MMO since 98 and this is the first one to hold my interest for this long in a while.There is a LOT of false info out there going "wah wah wah pay to win wah wah." I will tell you there is legitimately NOTHING in the cash shop that will make you better than anyone else, and very, VERY few items you cannot just buy with in game currency. The cash shop in game is, at best, "Pay to hurry up." As it will allow you to become more powerful, FASTER, but nothing anyone else cannot obtain through time and effort (the only meaningful way :D )

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This game, like all the others from Cryptic, is a pay to win and pay to play game.There are curently 5 classes to pick from.The PVP needs to be renamed play the thief or die, as the thief uses stealth, they can kill you while they are hiding,  and you can not do anything to stop them.  I do not ever see a thief in the real game, so the players just make one soley for pvp.The classses are not like the D&D game system at all.  The cleric can not turn undead, all they do is heal, they can not do any damage and use a magic missle type attack.  The ranger class is very weak, you should only use the basic powers you start with as higher level powers actually do less damage then these as you level up.  The wizard controls people and can "freeze" enemies which does not work all that well since anything bigger then a minion is immune.  The other 2 are fighters, one tank and one high dps warrior.Everything takes astral diamonds, or real money called zen, everything.  You pick up an item and need to identify it, it costs a scroll you pay for with astral diamonds.You want good equipment, a mount, a companion it all comes out of the astral diamonds.Guess what, they are hard to earn!!!At the beginning levels you can do 1 skirmish for 1000 astral diamonds and if you do it during the hour of the day that features skirmishes you get an extra 1000 for a total of 2000 for that 15 minutes, assuming that there are enough people on at your level and on your map to get into the queue.  You can also do dungeons daily to get 3000 astral diamonds but some of them take 90 minutes or longer depending on who you have on your team.Guess what, you want that good gear, it will run you 300000 or more astral diamonds, per piece, you do the math here.Of course you can always swipe your credit card and get 1 million or more astral diamonds, I mean they even have an option for you to spend $200 real dollars all at one time to make it easy for you to play their game.I did pick yes to recommend this game.It is fun to play, to try out the 5 classes and run some missions.You will get to your own point of saying, that is enough.  After your 3rd time in a row of being killed by someone who spent $200 for their pvp gear or maybe after spending more astral diamonds on identify scrolls running through a dungeon then you actually make. That point will be up to you.So hop in here, please, so that I do not have to wait 30 minutes in each queue to play something.  :)___________________________________________________________________________________Okay this is edited after module 3 came out, the icewind dale.  At this time I have put in another 50 or so hours trying out the changes to the new hunter paragon path and the new module.  When I first looked at this game I read the first review on the forum.  It had a guy who had spent over 900 hours on the game and did not recommend it.  I thought that was kind of stupid, who would spend that long on a game and not recommend it.  SO HERE I AM RAISING MY HAND AS WELL. I am changing my game recommendation from yes to try it out to NO just stay far far far far away.The price of 1 piece of real Zen, real money is now maxed out again at 500 astral diamonds.  Pay attention, you will earn 1000 astral diamonds for every 15 minute skirmish you run.  So that means if you spend 15 minutes playing a skirmish match and trade in your astral diamonds you will get 2 real zen.  Now take a look at the Zen store, you want that nice cheetah mount, it will run you 3, 500 Zen.There are players in the game who have multiple accounts, multiple meaning up to 50, who just run bots on all of them to farm astral diamonds.  I now see why they do that.There really is no fun way to get astral diamonds.  You can rerun the same skirmishes daily, assuming it is the skirmishes hour and make 1,000 astral diamonds per one, remember the longer ones will take you 15 minutes each or longer.  You can do the daily dungeons for 3000 astral diamonds, remember they will take you up to 90 minutes to do that.Okay so the new area, whoa what a bummer.  First you need to be level 60, current game max.Then you need to have epic level gear so that your gear score is over 10000.Then you need to have level 3 boons unlocked from either one of the grinding campaigns at the end.So basically, only those players who have done everything they possibly can and are still playing.Then there is the new PVP part, since the game was so unbalanced to start with, they now will reward those players with even more power after spending $300 real dollars or more on PVP gear.At the time I am writing this I have 4, yes 4, different lock boxes sets stacking up in my inventory.These are boxes where you have a very tiny chance to get good gear, or a new mount or a companion and they all take Zen, real money, keys to open.So I have tried every single class, both paragon paths for each, I have beat the game, max level on all of them.  I have written a ton of helpful hints for new players and now done a review twice.  I wish I had all that play time back now!!!!It just gets worse and worse as Cryptic nickel and dimes you to death at the end.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												I used to adore this game. It says on Steam that I only have about 70 hours played, but that's because I used to play it on the Cryptic launcher instead of Steam. I've played a lot more than that.But lately, they've stopped producing content for people who can't or won't pay for things. I'm all for having items and even certain questlines be pay to play, but whole classes and races? The new and ridiculous "events" are annoying and useless. They get in the way of actual gameplay! I'm trying to kill this boss, and a "you just got a -insert stupid name for item necessary for event-! Here's a large popup box and a new quest!" And suddenly I have to rush to click out before the boss smashes my unresponsive avatar into a pulp.The game is super unbalanced, too. Want a tip for how to breeze through early levels? Pick Hunter or Cleric, the two most OP classes. Mage is also pretty good- the ability to eliminate your enemies ability to move or attack is pretty OP. Less awesome damage, though. The game is never hard unless you go somewhere above your level. The monsters are nerfed to hell and back.There's also no variety. I used to love the dungeon crawls, but after the first thirty or so, their novelty wore off. And they are no longer worth the cliche grinding of "kill 20 imps" to get to. Every world, every quest, every single thing is exactly the same throughout the entire game! "Walk through absently designed dungeon. Interact with switches. Kill monsters. Kill boss. Done."This game hints at awesome customization with the character creation and the class/race quests and objects you can get to open more parts of the game. But none of these are expanded on in any useful way. They're token efforts to make players feel better. The only one I came across that had any kind of interesting class/race quest was Scourge Warlock! For all I know, Dragonborn or Moon Elf might have it better. But I wouldn't know, because they're behind a paywall!Honestly, the cashgrab aspect is probably losing them more money than they're making. If players are leaving because the game sucks without money being added in, make it a pay to play and move on. Plenty of games make plenty of money on that system. But if you don't have players to buy things, no one buys things. I would happily buy some of the beautiful companions and mounts and costumes if I had the money available. I would gladly buy the weapons and other cool things. But I refuse to be fleeced for the ability to play all of the actual game parts of the game! A free to play game should have the ability to buy extras. Not the ability to buy mroe of the game.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Game is an insult to The Forgotten Realms franchise and a slap in the face to it's creator Ed Greenwood, if your expecting an Advanced Dungeons & Dragons experience you'd have a better chance at Dungeons & Dragons Online.~ Numerous issues listed below:- Performs substandard no matter what build your desktop is (and I'm running off a i7 Quad Core @ 4.4Ghz and two SLi'd GTX 780s with 16gb DDR Corsair Veng Ram and this game runs like a slug)- Game is overpopulated with gold spammers and the community devs do nothing to address the issue at hand- Game is Pay to Win - cannot access better companions unless you pay an absurd amount of money basic blue quality one is 29.99$ USD- Combat is Clunky at best more like Two Worlds when it was first launched; complete inbalances with classes- Contradictions involving Lore if you've read any of the Lore Books or The Forgotten Realms Campaign Booklet- Magic System is mediocre heavily favors melee characters over spellcasters (not unforeseen as most MMO companies seem to have some unrestrained hatred towards anything that doesnt swing a giant metal stick); game contains 4% of the spells in PhB, devs add their own versions of spells which contradict pre-existing spells.- Alignment System forces you to play Good/Lawful or Neutral no option or flexibility to be Chaotic or Lawful Evil or Neutral Evil (completely biased against anyone who wants to play the greedy backstabbing merc or someone who wants to dabble in Necromancy)- Servers latency is worse than a 64k Dial Up Modem, constant disconnects.- Uses the Awesimium Process which is considered spyware to monitor your computer (possibility it's recording http sites you are visiting so it can spam your registered email with junk mail later)- Character Proportions completely wrong; Tiefling look like full Daemons unlike what they look in AD&D of a mix of human and Daemon depending on the Generation the Tiefling is.- Limited Imagination of the Dev Team and "Imperfect World" as me and my friends call them.- Little to no Customer Support; never address the issue with all of their games it has taken 1 year 3 months for them to get the mailing system somewat function again in STO; many quest markers have issues such as bugging or not working properlyAll In All horrible game to play not worth the time or effort invested.((I dont play through Steam I played through their PW client))

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												This game was pretty good when I first played it. But I guess there was something I was overlooking when I first played it as well that basically is the worst thing ever.This game is a cash grab. Just look at the price of the DLCs and that says enough. See all those people running around on cool mounts? Gotta buy em, otherwise your stuck with a plain Jane horse. Companions? Money. Crafting? Money, Items? Money. Dungeons? Money. Money Money Money. Everything in this game has a price tag and while the in game prices aren't too bad, that's where they hook you.♥♥♥♥♥♥is cheap and odds are you'll get "Something" of use out of each random bag you buy meaning you'll keep spending gobs of money. Really though it's not a problem if you're not stupid.I spent upwards of $45 on the game with in game purchases and played the game for about 4 months, so I'd say I got my  money's worth out of the game. It was interesting for sure, but endgame content was non-existent at the time.The quest immersion is great, with actual things happening in the quests, plus the toolset to build your own quests makes this game pretty good.Classes are bland and generic, but then, what do you expect from Dungeons and Dragons. They've never really been the most creative when it came class variety or uniqueness. Likewise with the race selections. Class mechanics are fun and interesting but lose their flair quickly.Dungeons are brutal in length and boast a pretty hogwash set of mechanics for any fight. Just pick one boss from any level dungeon and they either suck to fight against because the mechanics are annoying, or the mechanics are so bad that the boss is broken or too easy.Leveling up from min to max takes almost a month of casual play to attain, less if you're hardcore, so that's not bad.Save your money when playing this game as it doesn't offer much once you hit max level and most of the things they offer for you to buy are cosmetic in nature or offer only slight boosts to your character. You can pretty much skip over this game and not miss out on anything.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Curiously, I actually enjoy this game. The game itself is a strong MMO, if a bit outdated on the graphics end. My reasons for giving a bad review is the 'free to play' claim. While I have no real issue with a game that allows players to purchase the best gear, this should be a shortcut - nothing more. It is technically true that players CAN access the paid content by trading in-game currency for ZEN (the real money currency), the amount of time to get even a small quantity is highly limiting. But this isn't the major problem. The major problem I have is that it seems like everything in the game is locked behind that pay-wall; need more bags? Zen. A mount upgrade? Zen. Bank slots? Zen. Character slots? Zen. Re-spec? Zen. Access to the [current] best-in-slot gear? Zen. Better companions? Zen. Upgrade companions? Zen (or an astronomical anount of ingame currency). And the prices are, quite frankly, offensive: 16 bank slots on a single character? That'll run you about $6. That's more than a character slot. Some mounts are $40. The lowest rank bag? $6. Whoever priced this stuff needs to lose his job - and everyone who actually paid these prices is only enabling this mess. I want to see the game succeed, because I enjoy playing it. But that isn't going to happen if everyone actually pays their exorbant prices. Finally, I was forced to post this here because the developers refuse to allow posts about thier 'pay to win' pricing at all in their forums. They know it's an issue, and their response is to be adversarial - they clearly don't treat their customers with respect and think of them as little more than piggy banks.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												I started playing this game out of boredom and found quite a few hours to do the starting quests, up to level 60.Since I am no classic MMORPG player, my review is mainly based on my experiences in that game without direct comparison to any of the other billion MMORPGs out there.Lets start with variety:You have to choose a certain race and role on the beginning. Each role has it's own abilities. Depending on what skills you use later on, you can fulfill multiple purposes in each role.The game is quite interesting on start and it's fun to try out new abilities as you level up and get your first horse or companion. At least on start you get the impression of following some sort of storyline, doing several different things. After a while it gets very repetitive since quests quickly change to a pure seek and destroy.Finishing the first "plot", you will be sent to the capital city to a certain officer that offers new quests which allow you to visit other places.Most places are fairly nice to look at (depending on your settings) and the level design is pretty interesting in several cases. You get to fight a variety of enemies, a few of which have specilized abilities as you progress into higher levels.Second point would be fighting and the skilling tree:Fighting requires some concentration as strong enemie's attacks are displayed on the ground as a warning. These warnings and some slow mob's attacks are supposed to be dodged by running away or staying out of range.The skill tree offers a variety of different spells and abilities. These are divided into:-"daily powers", which supposed to be strong spells and need action points to be filled up, likely through fighting.-"free powers", which are started using the left and right mouse button and can be seen as a variety of basic attacking techniques.-(red powers?) ...are what you would call a spell. Cooldowns, damage values and/or custom effects.In addition, you get a variety of so-called "talents" that start with basic ones and advance into specialized talents that would power certains aspects of your normal abilities.Experimenting with these to find your own playstyle is interesting.So much for the major gameplay. Now off to the (many) points why I wouldn't recommend playing this game at it's current stage:My main point would be the lack of originality and heartblood.Everything you get to do has already been there many many times in countless other MMORPGs. After a nice start, the game quickly breaks down into loveless quest design and the further you go, the more confused you get.A constant flood of items without any sort of explanation about the point to it fills the inventory. Every time you figured out what to do with one of those strange new coins you found, the game is telling you to collect another 2 kinds of coins. The sheer amount of different "currencies" is nuts, while the majority of these will be outdated by the time you figured out what they are for.Huge areas with different questing points of any kind of importance spread all over make it very hard if not impossible to orientate on which plot you are actually working right now and where you may want to get something special from.The progress after the first levels is very quickly nullified and the game wants you to spend many hours on tiny steps forward. If you want to use the things you find, you are supposed to collect immense amounts of points in certain "currencies" the further your level progresses. The game very quickly yells at you "BUY OUR STUFF OR YOU WON'T GET ANYWHERE".It may be free to play, but it's very close to "pay to progress".As soon as you get to fight in a group, you quickly lose track of what's going on. Insane amounts of special effects from the players, their companions and the minions often make it a lag fest where you see nothing anymore and steer on your cooldowns to use the next spell on the "blazing-green-red-white-yellow-blue" part of your screen where you saw a dragon a few minutes ago, hoping he's still there.Going over to the serverside:Terrible server performance and countless bugs make playing a mess quite often. Constantly brought out new content keeps flooding the already messed up system. Reported bugs do not seem to be worked on in time - if at all.Since the content of this game is too huge to break down most things, I tried to keep it at a minimum. There are many more things I didn't like about this game. Unless there are major changes (keyword is major), I cannot recommend playing this game.

												I cannot blindly recommend this game without knowing what the potential player is looking for.  The game doesn't appear to be very deep regarding NwN/D&D lore, so if that's what you're looking for I'd think purchasing a copy of Neverwinter Nights or Neverwinter Nights 2 a good idea and seeking out a player run persistent server. If you're looking for a game with a good combat engine, and some pretty fun multiplayer (with friends) then i can see this game being a good fit, especially considering The Foundry and the idea of playing player made content (which i have yet to experience but read its quite good). On the other hand it does seem to be buggy and laggy in high populated areas, and if you're into MMO PvP, stay away.  Just looking at whats in the in-game-store, its quite obvious this game is pay to win.There is also some weird issue with censorship on the Perfect World forums (Chinese policed internet?).All in all, id only recommend if you have some friends to group with, and are not looking for anything to deep or involving.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
													Lost in translation between an MMO and the pen and paper source material, Cryptic studios has birthed a tepid monstrosity of classic dungeons and dragons.  In lieu of a glorious celebration of problem solving, fierce combat, and character interactions, we're given a series of adventures so generic that it brings up comparisons to decades prior.  Game mechanics similarly suffer a compromise between core dungeons and dragons concepts from fourth edition, and traditional MMO fair.  While it isn't necessarily terrible, especially for a free game, it doesn't warrant our attention either, and I'm stuck wondering who it appeals to.  	Forgotten Realms beckons adventures to sally forth to the wonderful locales such as Neverwinter, Icewind Dale, and other notable cities to defeat the evil Lich Queen Valindra as she does what all evil characters do; bring about death and destruction.  Story wise, it's so by the numbers that about an hour into it I was just clicking to get my quests.  The game throws so many tropes at you that it defies belief; a person you just met dying while trying to ingratiate himself to you, a fetch quest belaying the importance of resources to soldiers, and so forth.  There was even a quest to save three privates from becoming zombies, and after it was finished I wasn't allowed to save any more, dredging up memories of the infamous dickwolves strip of penny arcade.  These things aren't necessarily bad, as tropes can be used very effectively, but these are just sloppy.  	Continuing in much the same fashion, we're told that opportunists are wreaking havok on the land of Neverwinter, and we're tasked with helping out.  Only, I really didn't want to, because most of the people we're saving are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  I understand that conceptually, a MMO demands effort on the behalf of a player to reach rewards like enough money to buy weapons and armor.  When a city is in direct peril, and the fate of shopkeepers ultimately depends on me killing five zombies or collecting three leafs, fleecing me an arm and a leg to get a shield that will increase my odds of survival, or treating me like an a-hole isn't really motivation enough to get on my high horse to defeat the arch bad guy, or save the crown jewel from Nashkel, or even delivering a message to Sargent Whatshisname.  	Clearly, it doesn't take any chances on bucking the formula with the narrative, and largely it plays it safe with the game play as well.  After playing for a couple of hours, I can see that the team took ques from fourth edition, but the concepts don't really apply to an MMO.  Having encounters, daily's, and at wills stressed cooperation with your team and planning for the next encounter in the pen and paper version.  Here it means waiting a bit to mash e or q.  A cheap cop out for an MMO, timing is only a small part of it.  Your life is now preposterously high to compensate for a lack of a traditional AC system.  There aren't many choices to customize your character beyond putting points in different powers to level them up.  Purchasable/findable kits allow players to bypass certain skill blocks like thievery or dungeoneering, and all for the sake of looting, nothing more.  Essentially, it negates the importance of player choice, and emphasizes purchase power.	Perfectly exemplifying the translation from pen and paper to MMO would be the previous Dungeons and Dragons Online.  Where it succeeds, and likewise Neverwinter fails, is letting the player define their character in so many ways.  Not just in play style or character creation, but also letting the character choose how they interact with the NPC's, solve quests, and align themselves with the different factions.  The questing itself was extremely varied, and conjured amazing stories, like a drinking contest with beholders, or a carnival of the undead.  It was an amazing triumph that empowered the player to adventure and discover, not just run between quest giver and questing zone.  Here, there is very little the player has an affect on, which makes it feel soulless.  	I've spent little time with Neverwinter, so I can only hope that it improves beyond the initial image it conveys.  Reading more about the game though, I'm struck with my impression of tedium and depression.  We've all been “the chosen one” who can destroy the great evil and bring peace to the land, but rarely are we impressed enough to continue that adventure to its climax.  Neverwinter is an adventure for a different kind of player, and sadly it isn't the one Dungeons and Dragons traditionally appeals to.  If you're looking for an MMO fix, you can do far worse, and it isn't necessarily a terrible game in its own right.  It is uninspired, and in a market with far better choices, I can't justify spending any more time in the Forgotten Realms.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is not terrible, but it's not very good either. I love Cryptic games, especially the engine in which these games run. Both Champions Online and Star Trek Online are controller compatible. Why was that feature removed from Neverwinter I'll never understand. But let's ignore that for a second, I'm not a D&D fan so the lack of accurate lore other people complain about doesn't affect this review, I'm going to base it off gameplay, fun factor and economy.Let's start with gampley, this is a hybrid action MMO. You can move around and even avoid some attacks by moving but when you attack you're locked in place. Once you get used to that then the gameplay shouldn't be a problem. Except when we go and look at your efficiency in battle. Your level ups grant you attribute points to make the build that best fit your style, OK that's normal. But then we have gear and that's when things get out of control. You have a variety of ways to get the right gear for your build:1. Be on an efficient and active Guild willing to baby sit you while you farm it (good luck with that )2. Farm the currency you need to convert into gear. (I'll talk about the economy in a bit)3. Buy the currency to get the top gear (better known as Pay 2 Win)Which brings us to the economyAstral Diamonds is the top currency. You use it for almost EVERYTHING and you have a daily cap (to refine it) of 24,000 (if I'm not mistaken) Want to level up your mount? OK that's a couple of million astrals per level. Want to level your companion, Another couple of million of astrals. Plenty of things you want to buy you need astrals for, and even to transmute some gear. The entire auction house uses astrals as currency, so that armor that some dude was lucky enough to land on a dungeon run, well you may have to pay close to a million 'cause people aren't selling things for cheap. So that's farming Astral Events (skirmish) which take anything from 5-30 minutes (depending on the team and your level) for 1,000AD each run, Doing daily missions (which can take a very long time as some involve running the same instance multiple times in a row to complete and pretty sure the best one pays only 8,000 AD and that's unlocked at lvl 60) So basically you'll spent most of the day, every day trying to hit the refinement cap so you can get enough astrals to buy ONE piece of gear you want. Yes you can sell your stuff for astrals and those are already refined, but that means you'll have to spend hours farming good enough stuff to sell and hope to god someone has the "money" to buy it. Even worse if you want to level your companions, it's just not humanly possible and that's where the game falls apart. It's filled with these gold farmer things, you'll get bombarded through mail about them. It's gotten to the point where they not only have become the only viable option to play this game but that they have gone out of their way to destroy the exchange.You may be asking, what is the exchange? well Perfect World games use a virtual currency known as zen that you can only (mostly as you can do surveys and crap) obtain with real money to buy extra content on their individual stores. The exchange was created so that people with less income, but more free time, could play for astrals so that those with jobs (aka more money and less time to play) could still progress at the same rate by buying those astrals from players. That's a meta game on its own as you can play the market, buy when low and sell when high. The fluctuation usually caused by sales which PW was very keen in having them weekly. That way people would always want zen don't they? That's a bit troublesome but understandable, it is a business. But the problem in this situation is that most players don't like to think, thinking is forbidden in neverwinter, you can't be rational. Players are impulsive, which makes the job of gold farmers a hell of a lot easier. they managed to break the exchange hitting the cap of the most useful currency. What I mean by that is, 1 zen which is the equivalent of 1 cent, can get you (at the moment of this review) 500 astrals. So let's say you want to throw $20 worth of zen at the exchange, you come out with 10 million astrals. So all that effort farming that currency shows nothing for it. It is the currency that gets the game going but ultimately, the players have lowered its value to a point of no return. PW isn't doing its job protecting the game from farmers either, but again I understand it, ultimately they get a piece of the pie. A reduced piece if they throw some numbers, the ones getting the big bucks are the Gold Farming sites/services.How much do you need good armor? A LOT. Level basically means nothing, it's pretty much all in the gear, that's what make you a badass. I can't recommend this game, even with the Foundry which is a really good but gimped system that let's you create your own adventures. (gimped part, you can't have access to all the armor assets when creating NPCs) It's been over a year since I started playing and never felt like uninstalling the game, until now.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												It's hard to not recommend a game when you supported it through closed beta. It's fun for awhile but, IMO, the trick to making money in a F2P model is to not constantly force it in the player's face. I wouldn't say it's pay-to-win, and you could enjoy the game without spending a dime if you are ok with three big negatives. 1.) It's not D&D; 2.) It's nowhere close to being an expansion of the Forgotten Realms games; 3.) You will constantly be reminded that you can spend real money. That said, I did enjoy the dungeon-building. (I didn't build one, but I enjoyed playing others' campaigns.) It's worth playing around with for awhile but the revenue model takes away from a lot of the fun.*** EDITI agree with Random Gamer in that Neverwinter is not P2W. This is a case where I really wish that Steam offered a continuum rather than a binary Yes/No range of recommendation options. Of my three complaints, the only one that drove the thumbs-down was the amount of in-game promotion of, even if not necessarily the case, what appeared to be "driving one to a cash shop".That said, I admit that this sentiment is based on my experiences immediately into launch. Developers adapt and adopt different strategies for generating the income that they justifiably need and deserve; therefore, my complaint may not be as valid as it was at game launch.A good example of a game that, imo, started out with an excellent model for generating income is GW2. ANet's philosophy was that people would spend if they enjoyed the game....that advertising should be bottom priority way below content. Of course, in that case, one purchases the game...but that isn't going to pay for their ambition to evolve a living world (i.e., monthly new content). While there is a bit more in-game advertising than I think ANet originally planned, I think that their model has been successful in that a rather solid and loyal playerbase continues to puchase novelties and skins that do little, if anything at all, to make the player "better".I plan to spend a bit more time in NeverWinter. As said in the OP, I do recommend trying out the game. It's just a pet-peeve of mine (automatic deal-breaker) to have immersion interrupted by marketing. I prefer it when the game promotes services, perks, pets, etc. via the log-in screen, the game's website, and/or e-mail newsletters. Of course, this is also coming from someone who prefers having subscriptions as an option (e.g., EQ2's model).

content:
Posted: February 10
												A disclaimer - it's a game set in Forgotten Realms universe, but don't expect DnD-like gameplay. Now what should I say about this game...Neverwinter is a MMORPG, and a really good one. I was somewhat off for the first few hours, but the game gets better and better with every hour you spend in it. A disclaimer #2 - if you don't like timegate mechanic and grinding dailies don't read further.Let's start with some pros:+ Setting - I'm definitely a FR lover. You should know that Salvatore helped with writing some of the quests in the game. You will also meet some amazing characters like Bruenor Battlehamer, Drizzt Do'Urden or Minsc&Boo. + Music - wether you're in the heart of Neverwinter, traverse the Underdark or purge the Dread Ring of the undead you'll always be accompanied by really nice tunes. It's an MMO so obviously music does not play THAT BIG of a role, but the tracks playing at the background do not disturb you.+ Character development(bright part) - it's really well made. While power upgrading does not matter much, traits and boons can passively make your character stronger in different ways(for example make your trap also deal damage over time, and even stronger against immune targets)+ Combat - you're basically on the move all the time, combat is dynamic, there is a lot of dodging, blocking and watching out for enemy attacks+ Endgame - that is just my opinion but endgame is great. Dungeons are challenging(unless you get boosted by that 3k+ player), long, bossfights are fun. There is always something to do due to campaigns which not only give great rewards but boost your character stats via boons. Also progress is slow paced but significant enough to see the difference between those two items, 30-40 item levels or that one tier of your artifact. Cons- Hard to earn currency - getting AD as a fresh player is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Enough said. - AD to Zen converting ratio - Zen is that "real money" currency of NW. And while gathering AD to exchange for Vip(1k Zen - 500k AD) is not that big of an issue, trying to get AD to buy Zen while also managing your characters equipment is. Artifact here, refinement stones there, goodbye 120k AD here. - Outdated graphics - we're in 2017, yet graphics sometimes feel like a 2012 game. It doesn't look bad, it had actually aged quite well, but I think devs should consider making some upgrades here and there. - Character development (sad part) - boons from campaigns are a double edged sword. They greatly increase character capabilities, but good luck getting most of them. Some of them are after huge timegates(ToD, Dread Ring, Underdark) and others are just annoying to start with(Icewind Dale, ♥♥♥♥ you).My final mark would be somewhere around 7 or 8 out of 10. It's definitely a game worth at least trying out.

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												(This review deals exclusively with Neverwinter's Dungeon Creator and its community)I sunk dozens of hours (all before Neverwinter was on Steam) into the one redeeming quality of this game: the level editor. It's one of the best I've ever seen and writing, planning, and creating dungeons and quests is an awesome game in itself. I can't say enough in its praise. However, even this element of the game is ruined by the toxic community. Creators band together in level-making mafias to promote and upvote each others' dungeons (without letting on that they all in it together), and God forbid you ever give less than a 4/5 to one their quests--they will downvote your creations in retaliation.That this game's playerbase can take something wonderful like the dungeon creator and infuse with all the nastiness and spite of hardcore PvP left such a bitter taste in my mouth that I've never touched the game again.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Neverwinter is free-to-play, and we’ll get a bit more into pay-to-win, pay-for-convenience elements later.  The important thing here is players can get right into the game and begin playing without friction.Neverwinter boasts one of the best combat systems in any MMORPG on the market today.  It’s not the bogged down tab-target “sit-and-watch, hit 1 2 3” that the genre grew up with, nor has the pendulum swung all the way toward the oft touted “action-MMORPG”Every class in Neverwinter can solo quite easily, and because the combat is probably the game’s greatest strength, there’s no shortage of fun for those electing solitary confinement.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Initially, I felt actually happy and grateful for the chance to play a nice, decent MMORPG for free. But I've been around the gaming block long enough to see a variety of games and refine my idea of 'fun'. So, this review will particularly make sense to you if we happen to share a similar concept of FUN, applied to MMORPGS in particular. What makes a MMORPG *fun* then? To me, it would be:- An interesting storyline- A good level of customization and a reasonable amount of freedom- Some variety in the gameplay- A good implementation for social features (or at least a good excuse to socialize, because if I had to solo the whole content I'd just go for a single player) - Some PvP aspect (because again, the whole point of being online is to either cooperate with other players or kill em all, or both, basically)- A nice, detailed graphic look (but that's just personal)Thus said, I can't really expect to have it all, especially in a free-to-play title. But let's say that, for fun's sake, I'd be just happy to find at least 3-4 of these features in a mmorpg.How does Neverwinter score then, in the fun board?PROS+ beautiful visuals+ adult/mature aesthetics (no manga fluff nor japcutesy of any sort - counts as a plus to me, lol)+ UI done right: intelligible, intuitive, and graphically pleasant+ fluid combat style+ fluid mouse controls (I did appreciate the 3rd person view paired with the free mouse-look: that should be a standard for any game featuring some PVP)+ voice acting over walls of text, with the option to keep listening to the babble while you're doing something else in-game+ some variety for events here and there (raids, skirmishes, pvp)+ PVP indeed: tricky one, say a mixed bag. Altho it's maybe one of the aspects i enjoyed more about the Neverwinter experience, it's got many issues that never got resolved - like dumb matchmaking, overpowered pay-to-win dynamics, and the very repetitive nature of it (ONE small MAP ONLY for arena and one for RvR - which isn't even technically RvR -see cons)+ the foundry (always nice to look at someone else's creations)+ dungeons and+ dragons+ it's free to play..but well, pretty much, that's it. The whole thing kept me entertained for a total amount of ~1k hours or so, but in all truth, at least 1/3 of that time was me praying (literally) and hoping to see something harder-better-faster-stronger that sadly, though, simply isn't there.CONS- meh storyline (around the 3rd time you get 'the talk' from sgt. Knox, you've stopped caring already)- absolutely useless loot (after hours of quests, all you're left with to fill your baby backpack is a pile of worthless junk and a bunch of pennies - drops which would be actually useful for your class are so rare that you'd be tempted to just hit the shops.. but dem prices!)- way too many currencies, REALLY. I personally lost count of the various local insignia, the sigils, the seals, the ardent, celestial and whatnot coins. Glory? Zen? Black Ice? It's simply overwhelming, and it's probably there to prove your patience and push you to the shops- a shamelessly overpriced Action House and an even worse real-money shop: prices are simply unrealistic. 40$ only on a fancy mount, knowing you have to pay almost as much on bits and bobs like armor pieces or refining material you can't just do without if you wanna enjoy late game at least a little bit. Or even just to reroll abilities and skill points!- ridiculous prices usually lead to one main thing: GRINDFEST. Expect hours (or DAYS, or WEEKS) of joyless plodding through dungeons and minor uninteresting events just to farm enough Astral Diamonds to buy.. a key. - quests and dungeons get boring and repetitive after a while. Let alone the random seasonal events, which appear for a small few days window and induce players to direct the grindfest focus on those, for a slim chance to get mmm, a new pet?- the rigidity of the events calendar. That's even against the basic notion of free-will. You'll get something like a 45' span to do -say- skirmishes, and if you do them in that time-frame you'll get some bonus. Point is that, given the desperate amount of grind, everyone would rather do these activities when it's bonus time - therefore, outside of that time-frame, good luck queueing for dungeons or whatever else. - no real reason to socialize, apart from dungeons: the game is not open world, so you can't just put a group together for some good ol' free roaming. You've got your tiny shiny path to follow - alone. But even skirmishes and dungeons are not the ideal place to make friends: at the end of the day, everyone worries about themselves and the loot, which is a bit sad indeed.- no open world, just instances - I find them a bit limiting and claustrophobic.- crafting? forget about it. just read: GRINDFEST.- PVP, as I said earlier, is something that i really enjoyed in the game, but it's got its problems. You get the chance to take part in a sort of fake-open-world arena later in the game, but no one really plays it and it's not even a proper arena either: you'll just hang out in that specific area, maybe to do some fetch-quest, and will randomly bump into some other player from a different 'faction' who's there doing his own thing. To kill or not to kill? You might as well just ignore each other and finish your own silly quests in peace.- RvR which is not really RvR (my heart still goes to DAOC), it's called 'Gauntlgrym PVP'. Basically a capture-the-flag zergfest where you'll run around a lot, and if the numbers are on your side, you'll simply overwhelm the enemy faction. BUT, prior to getting into one of these matches, in order to be eligible for the queue, you'll have to take part in a series of hectic fetch-quests.TL;DRGive it a go if this is your first MMORPG maybe, just to see what's what. But if you're a more experienced player, looking for something new&challenging, you might get bored soon.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Always on the lookout for a great F2P game, and this one sure stands up. Yeah there are the WoW-geeks and stat-trads that like to gear score themselves out of any fun in MMRPG universe, but there is something for everyone here - especially D&D fans. Take the time to explore and appreciate the level designs, you will not regret it. Itis regularly updated for content and has its share of seasonal events and goodies. There is relatively little frustration with levelling (not really sure why power-levelling scabs / Astral gem / gold farming hax even bother, but even the laziest of lazy like to play games too I suppose). Levels can mostly be done solo or with a companion, but in the tradition of D&D, try to form a party or get your friends to play with you - way more fun! Overall very fun, gorgeous graphics and within the spirit of the venerable game.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												After playing this game for 17 hours or so and reaching level 22 on a Human Great Weapon Fighter class I say that this game is pretty good for a free to play MMO. I am pleasantly surprised how Perfect World Entertainment did with the D&D game.Aside from the questing and lore in the game (there is lots of D&D lore) the Enchanting and upgrading enchanting is done nicely and there is lots of Enchanted Chest drops.The queue system for daily's and groups is nice to see. I hate when a new MMO is released without the basic options to make playing fun.The "Foundry" (opens up to you at level 15) lets you create user based content and quests. There is plenty of daily quests to do and Dungeon Delves where you get some nice piece of loot when the time comes up for these options.Down Side I don't like is that to open the enchanted lock box's you need an enchanted key and that can only be bought on the market place and you need to use Zen to buy on the in game store.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Initially, I felt actually happy and grateful for the chance to play a nice, decent MMORPG for free. But I've been around the gaming block long enough to see a variety of games and refine my idea of 'fun'. So, this review will particularly make sense to you if we happen to share a similar concept of FUN, applied to MMORPGS in particular. What makes a MMORPG *fun* then? To me, it would be:- An interesting storyline- A good level of customization and a reasonable amount of freedom- Some variety in the gameplay- A good implementation for social features (or at least a good excuse to socialize, because if I had to solo the whole content I'd just go for a single player) - Some PvP aspect (because again, the whole point of being online is to either cooperate with other players or kill em all, or both, basically)- A nice, detailed graphic look (but that's just personal)Thus said, I can't really expect to have it all, especially in a free-to-play title. But let's say that, for fun's sake, I'd be just happy to find at least 3-4 of these features in a mmorpg.How does Neverwinter score then, in the fun board?PROS+ beautiful visuals+ adult/mature aesthetics (no manga fluff nor japcutesy of any sort - counts as a plus to me, lol)+ UI done right: intelligible, intuitive, and graphically pleasant+ fluid combat style+ fluid mouse controls (I did appreciate the 3rd person view paired with the free mouse-look: that should be a standard for any game featuring some PVP)+ voice acting over walls of text, with the option to keep listening to the babble while you're doing something else in-game+ some variety for events here and there (raids, skirmishes, pvp)+ PVP indeed: tricky one, say a mixed bag. Altho it's maybe one of the aspects i enjoyed more about the Neverwinter experience, it's got many issues that never got resolved - like dumb matchmaking, overpowered pay-to-win dynamics, and the very repetitive nature of it (ONE small MAP ONLY for arena and one for RvR - which isn't even technically RvR -see cons)+ the foundry (always nice to look at someone else's creations)+ dungeons and+ dragons+ it's free to play..but well, pretty much, that's it. The whole thing kept me entertained for a total amount of ~1k hours or so, but in all truth, at least 1/3 of that time was me praying (literally) and hoping to see something harder-better-faster-stronger that sadly, though, simply isn't there.CONS- meh storyline (around the 3rd time you get 'the talk' from sgt. Knox, you've stopped caring already)- absolutely useless loot (after hours of quests, all you're left with to fill your baby backpack is a pile of worthless junk and a bunch of pennies - drops which would be actually useful for your class are so rare that you'd be tempted to just hit the shops.. but dem prices!)- way too many currencies, REALLY. I personally lost count of the various local insignia, the sigils, the seals, the ardent, celestial and whatnot coins. Glory? Zen? Black Ice? It's simply overwhelming, and it's probably there to prove your patience and push you to the shops- a shamelessly overpriced Action House and an even worse real-money shop: prices are simply unrealistic. 40$ only on a fancy mount, knowing you have to pay almost as much on bits and bobs like armor pieces or refining material you can't just do without if you wanna enjoy late game at least a little bit. Or even just to reroll abilities and skill points!- ridiculous prices usually lead to one main thing: GRINDFEST. Expect hours (or DAYS, or WEEKS) of joyless plodding through dungeons and minor uninteresting events just to farm enough Astral Diamonds to buy.. a key. - quests and dungeons get boring and repetitive after a while. Let alone the random seasonal events, which appear for a small few days window and induce players to direct the grindfest focus on those, for a slim chance to get mmm, a new pet?- the rigidity of the events calendar. That's even against the basic notion of free-will. You'll get something like a 45' span to do -say- skirmishes, and if you do them in that time-frame you'll get some bonus. Point is that, given the desperate amount of grind, everyone would rather do these activities when it's bonus time - therefore, outside of that time-frame, good luck queueing for dungeons or whatever else. - no real reason to socialize, apart from dungeons: the game is not open world, so you can't just put a group together for some good ol' free roaming. You've got your tiny shiny path to follow - alone. But even skirmishes and dungeons are not the ideal place to make friends: at the end of the day, everyone worries about themselves and the loot, which is a bit sad indeed.- no open world, just instances - I find them a bit limiting and claustrophobic.- crafting? forget about it. just read: GRINDFEST.- PVP, as I said earlier, is something that i really enjoyed in the game, but it's got its problems. You get the chance to take part in a sort of fake-open-world arena later in the game, but no one really plays it and it's not even a proper arena either: you'll just hang out in that specific area, maybe to do some fetch-quest, and will randomly bump into some other player from a different 'faction' who's there doing his own thing. To kill or not to kill? You might as well just ignore each other and finish your own silly quests in peace.- RvR which is not really RvR (my heart still goes to DAOC), it's called 'Gauntlgrym PVP'. Basically a capture-the-flag zergfest where you'll run around a lot, and if the numbers are on your side, you'll simply overwhelm the enemy faction. BUT, prior to getting into one of these matches, in order to be eligible for the queue, you'll have to take part in a series of hectic fetch-quests.TL;DRGive it a go if this is your first MMORPG maybe, just to see what's what. But if you're a more experienced player, looking for something new&challenging, you might get bored soon.
