number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												I recently decided to give this game a shot, having not played an MMO since Guild Wars 2 shortly after its launch I wasn't going in with incredible expectations. I had heard quite a few complaints about Pay-2-Win trappings as well as balance issues within the game but was willing to go in with an open mind.The character creation was puzzling to say the least, I in part already knew I'd be rolling dice to create a character, but the question is why make the player sit there and reroll dice over and over to get their desired stat rolls when you could just let them choose instead? Rolling for stats makes sense in a in person Pen-N-Paper scenario where you get one shot at them. Otherwise there is absolutely no purpose except to waste the players time or to negatively impact new players who don't understand the mechanics.Then came the intro cinematic, it was jarring to say the least, I understand not every game gives you context in it's beginning cinematic, but this one goes out of its way to avoid any context whatsoever. On top of that the motions (and emotions) of the characters in the cinematic are jarring. I would say this isn't due to poor animation (the animation at the very least seems adequate) but instead seems to be due to a complete misunderstanding of how humanoid creatures interact with the World. Yes, it somehow looks that akward.I was willling to push through despite the previous reservations I had due to friends and reviewers alike giving it negative feedback as well as the poor first impression I had already received from just the intro cinematic and character creation, but then, upon entering the game World I was bombarded with "Admin notifications" that flooded both my chat log and also popped up on the very middle of my character screen. What were these messages you may ask? They surely must be important for them to be so jarring as to completely remove me from experiencing the game and trying to gather my bearings, right? No, in fact, they weren't. They were messages spammed to me by the "Admin" about people opening locked boxes/chests and receiving "rare" items. These messages are not only on by default, but they cannot be turned off or disabled in any shape or form. Both the jarring text that pops up and completely breaks all immersion as well as the spam in your chat log. You can't even make a separate chat log for just specific forms of chat (Guild, Party, etc) that won't be spammed by this as it is on permanently in all chat logs you create.That's pretty bad, right? But they have to make a buck, right? Well, certainly, Okay, so then, if I spend money on some sort of subscription, open a few boxes or buy some sort of premium one time membership then you can disable these messages, right? No, you still can't. This, my friends, is how you do free to play wrong, the Pay-2-Win is strong enough in the game already, but then for them to shove unremovable messages all over your screen that are there whether you support them or not? This prompted me to immediately close the game and uninstall every shred of it I could find on my system. I wasted two hours downloading the game, registering an account and patching it, but hopefully I saved someone else some time and frustration. If you value immersion, fair F2P games, intuitive character creation and story I can tell you from the very brief time I spent with the game you will get none or very shoddy versions of all of these. For context, I didn't get into a single battle before I ended up uninstalling the game, but I had over 20 messages about "Player XXX getting the Everlasting Hydra Mount of Smiting" flood my screen in that time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												I have a love for DnD games. I really have given this game a fair play. Over 400 hours of gameplay on the clock. Which I spent in part with guild mates, friends, and by myself.The game boasts great combat and exciting DnD stuffs to tingle your taste buds. For long time fans and newcomers alike.Each class feels unique and has its own challenges and paths to grow upon. Making you feel more epic with each ability you gain or master. The game is quick to award your heroic deeds with exciting loot and treasure, making it a fast to "grind" and a fun time with friends or guild mates. The graphics do look quite good for a F2P, and you never have to be stuck with one setting for a long period of time.There are so many great looking locations to feast your eyes on. Also a wonderful array of foes to slay! There is a great amount of fan service from the depths of the dungeons and beyond.There is also a wonderful custom map/ adventure maker! Allowing player generated content like I’ve never seen before in a MMO! You can take on the collective imagination of DnD fans from generations old and new. An outstanding feature and worthy of a look.But this game has a horrible underbelly, a dark one. I regret to inform you that it is rotten to its core as a social experience.It has fallen to the same fate of many F2P games. In the most typical and harmful ways.Complete with gold buying/selling, spam from bots, power hungry players with no social graces, and a terrible micro transaction system that hungers for your cash long after you have fed it. Boasting “sales” and “bonus packages”. Some of which are cringe worthy.  I have listed some of these grievances below. If you want to skip down to my final thoughts please do.There is a serious problem with the power balance due to an inflated economy system and broken auction house feature. Making it difficult to match your peers in PVP, gain knowledge in-game of items and their uses, and keep current in dungeon runs without the help of the richest guilds or deepest wallet. Crafting in the Neverwinter also costs you laughable wait times and pitiful returns. The pay components costing too much and the in game alternative being "buying gold" for powerful gems and enchantments. Leaving a huge gap between the player base.The micro transaction system has a list of sins which can go on for miles. For starters, you have to spend increments of money for a simple purchase, locking you into owning in game money and pitching it for items. You have to pay separate fees for every aspect of this game. Most of which is per-character. From expanding your bank/ inventory per character. To buying keys for random chance pots. My favorite being the respect token for changing your character abilities/ feats. It must be purchased every time you want to change your character’s play style. It is not unlocked, but purchased every time for any given character. Playing this game for free is very possible. But a long term investment in the Neverwinter can cost you the price 2-6 new titles or pay-to-play services with far better customer service.And formost..The game has attracted the typical internet fare, meaning you will spend more then enough social time blocking or muting your fellow gamers to get some peace from trash talk.  The community at large doesn’t respect itself, and you will be hard pressed to not to run into these types on a daily basis. Please, avoid this game if you are looking for a un-invasive F2P social game.  There are a few people making this game worth playing society wise. For every few guilds making the game open and fun for anyone. There are dozens of hateful players waiting for you.If this game was sub-based, or a standalone title, I would suggest to everyone I know!As a F2P. It’s a good thing gone sour.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Profoundly flawed due to an overt emphasis on gambling with RL $ via RNG and special items. However, the early user experience is remarkably intuitive, player generated stories/quests are in some cases truly quite fantastic. The game over all does capture the Never Winter setting flavour with an engaging overall ambiance. Attention to detail is quite refreshing with a number of NPC's obviously going about their lives. It's a small touch yet really gives a city or location a life of its own, that the players' characters are simply witness to.At a certain point it does become a level acquisition game complete with Kill x # of [creature], Find x # of [object] etc. It can get a bit tiring and boring if you've seen it all before. Otherwise not a terrible game.

												Breaks the bonds of standard mmorpgs. A detailed and thoughtful story paired with a stable and effective combat system ensures fast paced, addictive gameplay. The weight behind each attack makes me feel like I actually paid for the game. Speaking of paying, its much like Path of Exile in terms of you don't pay to win, you can pay to make your character, weapons, mounts, etc, look cool. Two thumbs up!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I was having a decent time at this MMORPG lite.  It was kind of simple and easy to get into.  The missions progressed rather easily and there is a lot of player created content that has passably playable dialogue.  But after I hit about level 35 or so, the difficulty of the mission progression seemed to stop suddenly and required me to start grinding out earlier quests or find parties.There were also a lot of minor issues like the pathing that guides a person around quests, tiny text errors here and there, and occassional problems with major party quests not updating as having been completed.  I could overlook these things but it did seem to lack a lot of polish, although in most respects very functional.Unfortunately this ended one day when after an update the game just failed to launch.  I tried repairing it through the ingame repair system, I tried uninstalling and reinstalling, and then I even tried a work-around I needed to do for Dota 2 which I had the same problem with once.  None of it worked and I can no longer play this game even though I had wanted to.  I just tried again after a few months and the problem still persists.  Oh well!  It's F2P anyway.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												For anyone who has played DDO and liked it you should definitely give Neverwinter a shot, They take the concept of less is more to a new level.  Combat is fast paced, skills are easy too use and understand and the graphics are nearly awe inspiring.  Having trouble finding a quest?  Can't pick your way through city streets?  No sweat turn on the Quest navigation and instead of just showing you which way to go on the minimap, it will also show you an illuminated path to follow in order too get you there.  Only complaint is the same one I have with most MMO's and that is lag in the big cities, however if you've got a burly enough of a machine this not an issue.

												Its a fun run of the mill mmo, slash'em up game. If your a hardcore D&D fan then im sure you'll find lots to hate, considering lore, and gameplay. Otherwise its a HUGE pay-to-play. The gold you get ( wich has the copper, silver, gold system) will only buy you the low level items, and some potions. The astral diamonds are used to buy better items, decent mounts, and deccent companions, but can only be gained through special task, such as daily missions. These are pains to do and in the end its usually not worth the work. The zen, a.k.a. the money you but with real money, is used to get the advantage while going anything. That means buying good items, good mounts, and good companions. All of these things being pretty important. Its such a pay to play, that all of the steam DLC's cost $450. Yep, thats right, 450 frickin dollars. Besides that, the combat is fun, and the game has some nice graphics, but there is the issue of everything else.4.5/10

												The game is nice, but the Foundry is what shines the most with the ability to play virtual Dungeon Master...  And since you can pretty well customize your social channel tabs, the annoying elements can be silenced efficiently to focus on your game style (even to the point of having the impression of NOT playing just another MMO at all... a blessing for the anti-socially enclined and generic grumpy old dudes just trying to play dungeons & dragons in friggin' peace)... The controls are fairly standard if you've played other games of the genre (Everquest, Diablo & Sacred series) and the learning curve is forgiving enough at the early stages, not so much later-on but that's just spicing it up. Would have preferred a more classical class system but I guess real challenges AD&D died after 2nd edition, when kids were too scared of playing with THAC0 rules and began having thieves throwing magic missiles :P But the game itself is still fun, in video game format.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												First off I need to say I am a huge Dungeons and Dragons fan. I have been since Baldur's gate and the original SSI Goldbox PC games. So, I jumped at the chance to play an MMO of my favorite setting and world. I have not been disappointed at all. If you are hardcore into Faerun lore and enjoy a good D&D themed setting and action MMO combat, then this is the place for you.I've been playing this game nonstop since early June of this year (review written at the end of August). Module 4 has just been released and I am enjoying it a lot. A lot of people say this game is "pay to win" and I simply have to say that this is not true. yes, you can buy all the best gear from the in game auction house because most gear is "bind on use" instead of "bind on pickup," so if you don't have use for a drop that you win you can sell it on the AH. This, being a free to play game, does have a cash shop, but except for some companions and the more expensive packs (dragonborn pack and hero of the north pack) you cannot buy "power." Everything is either cosmetic or utility.One thing I will say is that this game is very solo friendly. Even if you put real money into buying things in this game it is still a grind heavy game. You'll be grinding for weeks (and in some cases months) to get what you want. I personally really enjoy it as it gives me something to always do. The grinds feel involving and fun to me. Each of the different campaigns offers you ways to permanently increase the power of your character over time. The daily areas also have solo dungeons that end in an epic boss fight, so each time you do them it still feels pretty epic, even if you already know what to expect.Leveling in Neverwinter feels more like a typical MMO setup than D&D, but the D&D flavor is still there in everything. The stories are involved and there are several solo dungeons that you'll do in each zone as you're leveling up. These provide an epic single player experience and some of them can be quite challenging (Rime Fang, I'm looking at you). The zones in Neverwinter are somewhat gated and not open world in the slightest. If you've ever played Neverwinter Nights 2 for PC they feel a lot like that. Leveling speed is relatively fast. I was able to reach max level (60) on my first character within 3 weeks. This is an MMO that I will be playing for a very long time. End game group content is a lot of fun and quite challenging. The largest group you'll ever need for anything is 5 people as raiding has not been added to this game yet. However I do have to say one thing bad about this game. DO NOT USE THE IN GAME GROUPFINDER OR LFR CHANNEL TO FIND END GAME GROUPS! The game is unfortunately full of exploiters and gear score elitists that are very very unfriendly towards new players. BUT, there is something you can do! Join the channel /NW_legit_community and form your end game groups in that channel. Sure it might take a while to form a group, but you'll be with the best Neverwinter has to offer. This channel welcomes new players and helps them learn. This channel doesn't care about your gearscore. As long as its high enough to queue for the dungeon that is good enough to get a group in this channel. Its basically the only place outside of my guild that I will form dungeon delves with. The community is entirely player moderated and has been very successful for me. I was lucky that I found that channel shortly after I started playing.My name is Sharastrix@zshikara in game. Please feel free to ask me any questions you may have.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												I recently decided to give this game a shot, having not played an MMO since Guild Wars 2 shortly after its launch I wasn't going in with incredible expectations. I had heard quite a few complaints about Pay-2-Win trappings as well as balance issues within the game but was willing to go in with an open mind.The character creation was puzzling to say the least, I in part already knew I'd be rolling dice to create a character, but the question is why make the player sit there and reroll dice over and over to get their desired stat rolls when you could just let them choose instead? Rolling for stats makes sense in a in person Pen-N-Paper scenario where you get one shot at them. Otherwise there is absolutely no purpose except to waste the players time or to negatively impact new players who don't understand the mechanics.Then came the intro cinematic, it was jarring to say the least, I understand not every game gives you context in it's beginning cinematic, but this one goes out of its way to avoid any context whatsoever. On top of that the motions (and emotions) of the characters in the cinematic are jarring. I would say this isn't due to poor animation (the animation at the very least seems adequate) but instead seems to be due to a complete misunderstanding of how humanoid creatures interact with the World. Yes, it somehow looks that akward.I was willling to push through despite the previous reservations I had due to friends and reviewers alike giving it negative feedback as well as the poor first impression I had already received from just the intro cinematic and character creation, but then, upon entering the game World I was bombarded with "Admin notifications" that flooded both my chat log and also popped up on the very middle of my character screen. What were these messages you may ask? They surely must be important for them to be so jarring as to completely remove me from experiencing the game and trying to gather my bearings, right? No, in fact, they weren't. They were messages spammed to me by the "Admin" about people opening locked boxes/chests and receiving "rare" items. These messages are not only on by default, but they cannot be turned off or disabled in any shape or form. Both the jarring text that pops up and completely breaks all immersion as well as the spam in your chat log. You can't even make a separate chat log for just specific forms of chat (Guild, Party, etc) that won't be spammed by this as it is on permanently in all chat logs you create.That's pretty bad, right? But they have to make a buck, right? Well, certainly, Okay, so then, if I spend money on some sort of subscription, open a few boxes or buy some sort of premium one time membership then you can disable these messages, right? No, you still can't. This, my friends, is how you do free to play wrong, the Pay-2-Win is strong enough in the game already, but then for them to shove unremovable messages all over your screen that are there whether you support them or not? This prompted me to immediately close the game and uninstall every shred of it I could find on my system. I wasted two hours downloading the game, registering an account and patching it, but hopefully I saved someone else some time and frustration. If you value immersion, fair F2P games, intuitive character creation and story I can tell you from the very brief time I spent with the game you will get none or very shoddy versions of all of these. For context, I didn't get into a single battle before I ended up uninstalling the game, but I had over 20 messages about "Player XXX getting the Everlasting Hydra Mount of Smiting" flood my screen in that time.

												While I am often put off by free-to-play mmo games, this one struck me with one tle that I knew all too well. Dungeons and Dragons! This instantly brought me into the game, and cuased me to play it. While it may be just another mmo, it has the best combat systemin ANY MMO I'VE EVER SEEN. When you cast a spell upon an enemy, it actually feels like it. Unlike oer mmo's such as WoW or RIFT in which yout spam 1 consecutively with 2 or 3, this game actually has you use your mouse and q,e,r ablilities. While you may only be able to use 3 or 4 abilities because of this, it dosn't deny that this is the BET of mmo combat. While I didn't find the story or atmosphere entertaining, I found something that I couldn't find in other mmo's. The feeling as if I was actually fighting a wizard or a skeleton or what ever I had to fight. I was immersed in the world by the usage of their awesome combat system. It's not perfect, but I enjoyed it a hell of a lot more than WoW or RIFT. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Definatly a fun game, not just button mashing and dungeons that you can play with groups can be challenging sometimes. The typical missions are very easy and PVP is ok. After you complete the main game the game does become very repetitive and quite boring but the main campaign/story line is definatly worth playing and you will reach the max level cap (60) before you complete the game. Maps switch from huge to quite small but there are usally caves and dungeons to explore as well and you always run into other players even when completing the campaign. Takes about 60 hours to complete the main storyline and side quests to this game, after that you can do retitive quests and "campaigns" to get legendary armor for your character which can be quite boring but if you really like the game i guess you would still find it fun completing the same mission or killing the same dragon over and over and over and over and over for 1 item.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												NOTE:Pls Read about Elemental Evil more down in my Review as i can only recommend the Game until LVL 60!The Game itself is like WoW on many Terms as both are based on DnD Pan and Paper Game.However Neverwinter has (in my Opinion) the actual better Fighting System because it doesnt feel as Stiff as the WoW one because you get Feedback on Crits and the Characters actually do attack faster its hard to explain.On the F2P/P2W Aspect i can say it is like in many other Games.You CAN have everything free if you:1) Have no actual Life and play 16h per day.2)Accept that you will never have the Gear to be good at PVP (but you are gonna be good enough for Raids and Stuff)3)Have Sense for Economy and trade Stuff to make profit (its not really that easy but i read about it but i honestly never tried that.Also you can get the Premium Currency called "ZEN" for free as Exchange for  "Astral Diamonds".These Astral Diamonds are the Currency for the Ingame Market and Auction House,so basically everything besides the Premium Items.These Diamonds you can aquire by:1)Completing  Daily Quests.2)Trading Items to other Players for Astral Diamonds.3)Buying ZEN with real Money and exchange them for Astral Diamonds (Thats the way to speed up getting actual decent PVP Gear.4) Opening Chests with  Keys you can aquire from Premium Store for a little amount of ZEN(sometimes yields more Astral Diamonds if you sell these Items but its quite a gamble.Having these points said the Game is pretty similar to WoW but i prefer it due to the more responsive fighting System and the PVE Quests are more obvious when it comes to moving from one Area to another(in WoW i actually had to google to which area i had to go next cause there was no followip Quest)Also all the Expansions in Neverwinter are free so if you dont wanna play PVP ever you can enjoy this basically for free.~~~~~~UPDATE on LVL 60+ Content introduced in Elemental Evil Expansion~~~~~Sometime ago there was the Module(Module = Expansion in Neverwinter) 6 introduced to the Game called Elemental Evil.Many Players looked forward to this Expansion,but unfortunately i must say it isnt that good.That is mainly because Cryptic (the Game developer) added new Areas to the Game,which is always a nice thing, but these areas are recycled from the old ones and only contain the typical generic MMORPG Quests.Also to make things slower you have to complete 3 Times 16 Quests for each Area but you can only have 4 Quests at once.And these Quests are very boring so i dont recommend this Stuff.Also the Levelcap was raised with this Module from 60 to 70.Many players expected new Endgame Content to come because of that but Cryptic just recycled the old Areas to Level 70 and every Player has to grind his old Sets again which makes many Players leave the Game and i can honestly understand that.So overall i would give this module  a thumb down but as the game itself to lvl 60 is still very enjoyable i will leave it at that but i cant recommend trying to get through these Quests its not worth the afford.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.Eat.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Being a Dungeon Master (Game Master for Dungeons&Dragons) has really influenced my vote as to whether this game is good or not. If you are not familiar with Dungeons&Dragons and the concepts related to it than this game may not be as enjoyable for you. This game is set in the world of the Forgotten Realms, bringing back memories of Baldur's Gate, The Legend of Dritz, and so on. There is a lot to like if you are into D&D, so if you are into D&D than this game is a must. Everything is lore/story driven, so those who like it that way will be pleased indeed. Anyway, onward to the pros and cons.Pros-Graphics, they look just plain awesome. Although graphically it is on par with many of the other popular MMOs out there, again, if you like D&D than you can really appreciate how the game looks and feels. It feels like it would look if a Dungeon Master described it, anyway, moving on.Customization, basically unlimited character customization. Although you are limited into choosing one class, you can literally develop your character however you see fit. In terms of character creation, you can literally create your character to look like anything, almost all of the player characters are entirely unique from each other.Combat, although the combat is somewhat like any other MMO, if you are a D&D player than you will really enjoy the combat. With skills straight from the tabletop RPG, it really puts on the "This is a D&D" seal on the game. Lots of skills to, more than you can possibly keep track of and use.ADVENTURE CREATION! There is a system that allows you to create and post your own custom adventures/quests into the game for others to enjoy. For a Dungeon Master, this is a HUGE positive trait that I will always love about this game. With nearly unlimited potential, you can create whatever you want, literally! My current project using the system is to recreate an adventure that I had with my real D&D group, but in the Neverwinter game. I would have given this game a positive review just for it even if the game was horrible.Cons-Unoriginal, the game itself feels like any other MMO to be honest, although there are some very defining points that set it apart. The combat, controls, and quests just feel like your typical MMO, lacking in variety. But the overall presentation of these quests are actually really good, lots of good story elements and lore.Pay To Win, I would say this is a more or less kind of thing. Although if you play the game a lot and get by without paying, the game itself wants you to spend your money on it. Whether it be cool costumes or mounts or anything else, if you want a really cool character be ready to pay. At higher levels this isn't really a problem, but early on you will be targeted and prompted to buy things.Conclusion-The game itself is very good, and a must for any D&D player. I highly recommend the adventure creation aspect of the game for any Dungeon Master, there is a lot of potential in something like this. Lots of great story/lore, plus untold stories created by players like ourselves! Anyway, that is all for now, hope this helped!May your adventures be many and always end in reward!-Donoknight, Founder of Tabletop RPG Gamers League

												Anyone who's saying this game is completely pay-to-win is a complete dumbass. You only pay to proceed faster in the game and it's a common aspect of all MMORPGs nowadays. PVP here sucks (in a way) so there's no point rushing for PVP items. On the PVE side, the loots from dungeon raids are relatively generous so reaching 2.4K gear score can be done in less than 3 days after reaching level cap ---- oh btw, reaching level cap (lv70) is a breeze even without exp boost from guild boons, VIP or whatever source. Another important factor to consider is that this game is highly skill-based. Getting the top-line equipments won't save you if you're a stupid player. There's more to say but I guess this is enough to prove my point.Come on guys, be fair and give it a shot first before constantly whining about everything. Been playing MMOs since Ragnarok Online (around year 2000-ish) and definitely I couldn't say Neverwinter is the best but hey, it's better than most games out there right now. If you ask my rating on this game, I'd honestly say only 7.5-8/10. Still needs a lot of work but since I'm hooked, it's definitely good. content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												     While Neverwinter leaves a bad taste in some folks mouths, I found it be fun, fast, and creative.  Sure, every free-to-play game has to chase the paper a bit,  but the only things that aren't available to the average player are upgrades that make the playtime faster.  And honestly, you might be cheating yourself if you try to shorten the amount of time you put in for stuff.  For me, Neverwinter is about following traditional DND ideals in a new way, with a cohesive vision and storyline.  There isn't a large free-roam world, but I find it refreshing to actually know where to go and what to do.  There's plenty of surprises and secrets, there's plenty of tough battles, and there's a lot to do.  When you max out your levels you've only really played about half the game as it is.  The foundry (playermade quests) adds an ever expanding option as well, so it's tough to get bored with Neverwinter.       If you're in to competitive multiplayer however, that's where Neverwinter falls short.  The PVP is fun and fast paced, but at the higher levels there's a noticable advantage between folks that invest money and those who don't.  As stated before, you can get almost everything in the game through playing, but the amount of time you have to put in as opposed to the few dollars you can spend leaves you a bit discouraged.  The money system in the game is pretty weird too, as you have Zen coins, Astral Diamonds, and Gold/Silver/Copper.  The gold you get from killing monsters is nearly worthless as you progress, and most in-game trading is done through the Astral Diamonds.      I think that this game is an overall success, and If you're on the fence, I'd say go ahead and play it- It's free.  You level rather quickly anyway, so you can get the gist of classes and playstyle without delay.  Happy Adventuring!

												So this is my second review, after that horrible train wreck mod 6-9 were. Neverwinter is back, and better than ever! content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Gameplay:Neverwinter Online deviates from its traditional itirations of D&D gameplay. Hybridising elements from action RPGs like Diablo and staple MMORPGs like World of Warcraft and Star Wars.Considering its Free-to-Play nature, there are no surprises with the omnipresent harsh grind to get better levels and items. Often tempting the player to make in-game purchases [overvalued to say the least, only providing limited relief from the grind].The game itself is young - needing polishing in its class balancing in both PVE/PVP, attendance to bugs/exploits, map pathing to say the least.The community itself is growing steadily, with the simplified action gameplay and D&D nostalgia appearing to be some of the draws.Customer Support:Despite the promising appearance of the game, it is hugely let down by its flippant and poorly accounted support services.Appeal tickets appear to be unanswered for days, then the tardy reply is often a simplistic resolution [often to the account holder's disadvantage]. Repeated follow-ups by users may be met with harsh penalties. Inquiries to detail Terms of Service infringement reasons are wholly ignored.***NOTICE***I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND NEW AND PRE-EXISTING PLAYERS TO WELL INFORM THEMSELVES OF THE PUBLISHERS "TERMS OF SERVICE" IN THEIR ARC CLIENT!**I personally found certain sections of their terms rather ridiculous and would only serve to benefit the publisher; leaving the account user bereft of protection against scams, hacks, and misdemeanors from the online community.Impression:The game is enjoyable [in terms of combat and its pace] early on, though current business model affecting gaming immersion and lack of accountable player support damages the experience of the play through to an extent.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												as i'm sitting here typing this i've loged in 31.7 gameplay hours. this game is fun. how is it fun? lets itemize a bit.lets start with the graphics. they clearly tell you what's going on, no problems. for those who place more importince on grahpics that i do: exelent specal effect displays that do not hamper the view of what's going on. easy to look at terrain and charcters, no eye sores here. what else do you peeps look for? dunno'game play, the combat (of wich there is plenty) is a bit more frantic than most mmo's i've played. you have to aim at your target, simply selecting it then pressing keyboard keys doesn't work, aim or you won't be able to hit with single target attacks, aoe attacks are easer to pull off, just make shure you are pointing in the correct direction. oh, and watch out for the big red areas, they show up when something hostile is about to land an attack there. about a dozen charcter races and (currently) 6 distinct classes. you get some tokens to rent a mount from a quest, let you know if you want to purchase one, or just keep walking. if you want to buy a mount there are an assortment of styles and speeds to choose from. and you can have a hierling, you get one of your choice free when you complete the tower zone, others can be purchased with ingame coin or (i assume) from the ingame store for real money.questing: the quests have decent varity and no confusion. read the quest discription, follow the provided waypoint. easy enough, as long as you can survive whatever gets thrown at you. if a new area is to hard, back up to your last zone and help peeps with there quests, another lvl or two makes a big difference and they will apreacate the help. or just run the dungeon a time or three more, this will also help peeps with their questing.sound? good. with 5.1 i have a good idea of everything going around me, on my comp screan or not. npc voiceovers are nicely done. combat noises are also nicely done. but this game is one of the very few i have problems with the voip, although i am apparently an exception here, as most i've talked to it works just fine for.crafting, what is an mmo without player crafted goods? at lvl 10 you can start crafting items from any of several professions. step one: hire a (free) assistant,the first one takes 5 sec, then have your assistant gather goods, refine gather goods, or make useable products. you can find crafting goods while out adventuring, this helps a bit. you start with one crafting work slot and get others by reaching various mile stones, wich you can read from the select a workslot space. you will probally will have the "get a profession to lvl 3" milestone first, and it doesn't take to long to get. somewhere in here i need to mention that when you make an item you have your assistant(s) work on it in real time. most tasks are in the neighhborhood of 10 to 15 min, some will take longer, however. when your hierling is done with the work, just collect the resule and (if you want to) have one of them start working on something else.community. in my exprience frendly peeps are the name of the game. need help, somebody will have a useful and polite answer in no time. friendly conversation is one of two topics i regulary see, the other is putting together a group for a quest.  gold farmers exist here, but just right click on their name, choose  "report spam" and they get put on your ignore list free of charge. no need to keep reading their spam. well, there was this one time i squelched somebody for rude coments to one of my toons, just right clicked and choose ignore for that person.i think this covers everything. oh ya, game is free to play, they appear to get their $ on optionals, other than needing to purchase everything indivudally. or paying for things that other games provide for free, i'm thinking about one you had to buy items with real world $ to speak in global. more charcter slots and keys for those lockboxes that get passed out like candy on hallowween are the only ones that i notice. 'course i don't brouse the real money shop, you might find usefull stuff there. thinking of, i may just get a couple of extra charcter slots to try out diff classes.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Best D&D RPG I've played since Baldur's Gate D.ABest MMO I've played since Runescape. Simply put; simple is king.  It's like a plug and play. You get it, read tutorial steps once and you are ready to go. It involves skill on a different level, not only do you think about your command combo's but you actually have to know where you will stand. you can see red circles for charging/casting moves from enemies, there is a very accurate dodge system that you have to use yourself by pressing "shift" (limited stamina). And many more various other powers, passive abilities, mounts and pets. It can be a very friendly community, because Neverwinter has a system where it parties you up, if you need/choose. No constant standing around waiting for a nice group to let you in to Clear Dungeons, Onslaught Skirmishes, and more.  This game is free, it's great.  I was convinced by the "what is Neverwinter" video. This game is worth a try by everyone, and it's definitly worth keeping. Try find a free MMO that is this easy to get into and offers as much fun.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Neverwinter is a pretty standard Cryptic MMO in that everything about the game is incredibly mediocre. The game isn't your typical "hotkey MMO" - you instead have only a handful of abilities at any given time. Because of the lack of keys I found combat to be very boring and repetive, but for people that don't really like the "bazillion and one things to remember" it may be a good thing. I personally wasn't a fan of it.A lot of assets are reused as well. For 30 levels I found myself fighting the same types of enemies in the same types of enviornments, and story wasn't compelling enough to keep me interested. Very little of the source material is actually important, the game is essentially a self-contained story and even simple things like the city of Neverwinter itself is built from the ground up to be unique, so people like myself that played Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights etc. really have nothing to look forward to in terms of revisiting these locations.Classes are very bare-bones right now, and while variety is well enough, it doesn't even begin to compare to the kinds of options Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate players are used to. The "die rolling" character sheet on character creation exists, but it doesn't feel like actual dice rolling. It seems as though Cryptic made it so there are several chances you can get and the game just flips between them to simulate you're rolling your stats. I spent maybe ten minutes re-rolling to get an unoptimal roll and it simply never happened. My highest numbers were always on my classes two highest stats, with one or two points favoring one statistic over the other. I never managed to get really high Charisma on a Fighter, for example.The biggest comparison I can make to the combat system is Tera. The game has an "active" style attack and offense system in place, but for the most part I experienced no challenge whatsoever in a solo enviornment. In groups all of the content I experienced was trivial (especially in raids etc.). Maybe this changes as you get higher into the game, but I spent my 30 levels bored out of my mind and completely uninterested in what was going on story-wise. If you're new to MMOs in general, I think you will have a lot of fun, however. It strays far enough from the "WoW-clone" formula to be appealing in my opinion, but at the same time it doesn't take any huge liberties with gameplay mechanics or... anything else, for that matter, to really justify choosing to play this over the plethora of other MMOs that are available. Cryptic's use of the license is just pathetic, really. Apart from seeing "Neverwinter" in dialogue or on the map I was convinced that this was just another generic D&D inspired gameworld. When it comes to "is it ACTUALLY free to play?" I found the game to be pretty fair compared to other experiences I've had with this genre. At no time did I feel like paying for something would make the game easier, nor did I feel it was necessary to progress. With the research I did (I didn't spend dozens of hours on forums or Google so take this as a subjective opinion) the vast majority of things in the game that could be bought for real money were mostly convienence items. More bag space, faster mounts, armor/clothing cosmetics, that sort of thing. The game is using Cryptic's infamous "lockbox" system, however. And the middle of my screen was essentially permafilled with "SO-AND-SO OPENED A BOX AND GOT STEAMING PILE OF DUNG" so if you're not a fan of that type of marketing then beware that this game is very bad about that.In terms of content I found that the game was somewhat lacking. Crypic's "mission creator" system I experienced from Star Trek Online is present here, and it seems as though it's essentially been copy & pasted. This I found to be both good and bad. Good in the sense that there are really creative players out there that are doing Cryptic's job for them, bad in the sense that when anybody complains there "isn't enough content" most retorts will be "then play community-made content". The missions I played by players were varied, and while I never tried to make any missions myself, if the mission variety is any indicator, then Cryptic's tool is very versatile and seems to get the job done well enough.With that being said, it brings me around to my least favorite aspect of this game: the dailies. At an incredibly early level (approx. level ten) you are introduced to daily quests. If you're not familiar with daily quests, they are essentially very basic, oftentimes simple (but time consuming) quests that can be done on a timer (typically 12 to 24 hour period cooldowns). In Neverwinter the dailies revolve around PvP and player-made content. Once the initial "new" feeling wears off (just as any other MMO) the dailies become monotonous and tedius. The rewards are fairly bad as well, and never motivated me to invest a lot of time to complete them. Overall I was very disappointed in this game, and Cryptics consistency with creating average MMOs that adhere to a very strict formula. Being big into Neverwinter Nights I was continually let down with this game's lack of story and of license use, and in general the "safe" way Cryptic approached yet another MMO. Even more so since it lacks the sort of exploratory freedom of Star Trek, and the creative freedom of character of Champions Online. This game is a middleground to both of those games and as a result I feel it suffers for it. For the reasons listed above I simply can't (and won't) recommend this game to anybody but those that are extremely tolerant and/or accepting of the "standard MMO business" that has become so mainstream. And for those that are D&D enthusiasts, my advice, from one D&D fan to another, "move along; there's nothing to see here".

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												A average to good game at times, the free to play model they chose to use doesn't seem intrusive until around level 40.  If you're an item hoarder forget it, they give you a hobo's hankerchief and a broom stick to carry a jumbo jet's worth of items.  Unless you have money you want to spend.  The item progression based on apperance is sad to say the least, my character looked like he did at level 5 when he was level 45.  The dungeons are difficult and satisfying but there is little chance you'll overcome obstacles with a sub par group.  The combat is fast and fluid and the telegraph system is refreshing compared to slower MMO's but don't expect a lot of variety as you'll be using most of the same moves throughout the entire game.  You get a limited amount of Champion slots so pick what you want to play wisely or get ready to delete some hard work.  I didn't see a snow level... so it's literally never winter. 1-100 I give it a solid 70.  ***The low play time on here doesn't take into account the 50+ hours I put in before I connected it to Steam.***

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Neverwinter is a pretty fun MMO, while it uses a lot "MMO clichés", it is a fun MMO experience.I found myself immersed in the fun world that this game shows you. It has fun combat, a nice character creator and good graphics. This game also has a mode called "Foundry" where players create their own level scaled quests for other adventurers to play through. The only downside are the semi-repetitive quests and the lack of armor variety. But that aside, this is a great MMO and all of you who are looking for a fun MMO to spend hours in should definitely try this game.Graphics: 7/10Story: 6/10Combat: 8/10Customization: 6/10Atmosphere: 8/10Overall: 7/10

number of helpful: 35 of 70 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												NeverWinter is the best F2P-from-the-start MMO to date. By that I mean, disregarding MMOs that started P2P and then made the switch to F2P (eg. LOTRO, RIFT, et al.).There's a lot of content without ever having to drop a dime, not just in the core game itself, but because of the hundreds of player-made modules - some of which are quite good. Unlike PoE, which has aesthetic-only micro-transactions, NW does have boosts and gear you can buy, but all of it can be bought with in-game money (a lot, of course), and none of it is P2W.The game may not be for everyone because the combat feels different than your typical MMO (more like a third-person action-adventure game), but I quite liked it.PS. This is NOTHING like NWN or NWN2.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												If this was sold as a normal rpg, it would be similar to a tablet app. But for a PC MMORPG, this game doesn't have a publisher that have the player's gameplay experience in mind. Then again, not alot of other MMORPG's are blessed to have a "good" publisher.Edit: I think i wrote that late at night after I closed neverwinter for the last time. I wanted to emphasise the importance of mmo publishers to actively play their games. Perfect World Entertainment's attitude to critical problems with the game was simply to ignore them and publish new redundent and convoluting content. Eventually, the lore was a mess, ingame economy lay in ruins, and character progression rendered as a sad emulation to World of Warcraft.The only saving grace to this IP would be the control and combat mechanic. It's actually really intuitive and feels incredibly natural during PvP. Even with lag, the whole concept kept the feeling of control over my character in the game. Targeting with my mouse reticule is the future for mmos; tab targeting is you fighting the GUI before the GAME itself. I was going to play another game that has similar control/combat mechanic (Black Desert Online) but that is also FTP. I won't step into this genre until it cleans itself up.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												So this is my second review, after that horrible train wreck mod 6-9 were. Neverwinter is back, and better than ever! They fixed most of the graphical optimization issues, so running the game is no problem. Servers can still be an issue at times, but it's clear that they've been working on that as well. Gameplay is the usual neverwinter, at end game running dungeons is enjoyable again. The level grind from 60-70 is still boring and a hassle, can't really do much about that though huh? Some aspects of end game really push towards paying since it can feel impossible at times. Though the game is completely free to play, since everything necessary is obtainable in game. 8.5/10 Would recommend now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												First off, do not expect this game to be any thing like the Bioware games.  It is a totally new game engine and the HUD is completely differeent.  However, if you're a true fan of Faerun then you will thoroughly enjoy this game.  It's an adventure with a wonderful story line which follows the R.A. Salvatore novels of Neverwinter.  Valindra starts the game off by meeting you in the very beginning and you'll end up with and EPIC battle against her through several dungeosn.Now, for the game mechanics.  Personally, it was hard for me to get used to because I loved Neverwinter 1 and 2.  I played them ALL!  In fact, I was a huge Neverwinter Nights player when it was on AoL.  So, I struggled through the mechanics of the game and didn't really like it, but after playing from Closed Beta all the way up to the new module for Dragonborn Classes, this game is one of my favorite games of all times.Give it a chance if you're really a Faerun fan or R.A. Salvatore fan.  You'll fall in love real quick.UPDATE:  UNDERDARK MODULE---------------------------------------------------The latest update has shown great improvement since the horrible mistakes of Module 6.  There's still some lingering problems like favorite dungeons still missing and gold/diamond spammers are worse, but the overall direction of the game is doing better.  If you left because of Module 6 then you should return and check out RA Salvatore's new story line with his novel characters.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This was the first MMO I was genuinely interested in, being set in a D&D world AND Forgotten Realms AND paying homage to the old Neverwinter Nights series (sort of, though it's obviously different), so I thought I would give it a try. It turned out to be very solid for a free to play game and I've been playing it actively since.The game's presentation overall is really great. It's extremely easy to learn, menus are easy to use, the graphics look fantastic (with a cool one button "inspect" mode for taking nice screenshots or just looking around)  and the soundtrack is really good. There's loads of customization options for character looks and races also. Classes not so much but I'll get to that point later.Gameplay wise, it plays more like a hack n' slash action RPG than an actual D&D game. I think that's ultimately a good decision because not everybody can be expected to learn the whole ruleset just to play the game. While I would've liked to see way more D&D mechanics like alignments and skills being used, I think the system is fine and I adapted to it fast. Classes' skillsets are pretty limited too and only become more different later on, and the game does not have that many classes yet so you're bound to see lots of people playing typical rangers and rogues, but hopefully more are added later on. Overall the game feels "streamlined" this way so it's easy to pick up without having to worry too much about progression. But the combat at least feels crunchy and satisfying.The setting is pretty interesting, being set after the Spellplague, the world is very different and there's lots of interesting new stuff going on, especially if you are familiar with any past Forgotten Realms games / books at all (the game also heavily references Salvatore's new books), and it has tons of lore relating to pretty much everything. Places, characters and monsters also look and feel very D&D-like, and I think the game's art style overall is very similar to Neverwinter Nights 2's, just prettier with much better animations and character models.Then there's the Foundry which allows community created quests (with their own levels and everything) to be played in the game just like normal quests and that's a very interesting feature. I only briefly tried it so far but there's loads of good content available and anyone can make and share their own quests (provided you are at least a certain level). You don't even need to do anything special, you just walk up to a job board ingame, choose a quest, and the game does all the downloading and set up in the background for you. They play like modules for the old Neverwinter Nights games, if you're familiar with those, except they're integrated into the same game world. That at least ought to add replay value to the game.Lastly it's free to play which to me at least is a huge plus and so far I haven't encountered any content in the game that I would need to pay for which is great. I don't know about high level play yet (lv22 at the moment of writing), but for a casual player like me who isn't all about being super competitive, I think you can get along as a free player just fine. The only real downsides to the game for me are its lack of difficulty sometimes (most of the standard quests can be easily soloed) and limited roleplaying. So yeah...I would recommend it. :P You have nothing to lose anyway by trying it out, especially if D&D / NWN interests you anyhow.==================================================TL;DR with plusses and cons:+ Excellent presentation / quality for a F2P game+ Very nice graphics+ Easy to learn+ Fun combat, practically infinite content thanks to Foundry+ Good use of lore- Limited customization for classes- No actual D&D roleplaying (alignments)- Lacks D&D mechanics like skills- A bit too easy, especially if you stick to recommended levels.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This review is based on approximately 3 hours of interupted game-play.  Considering it is free to play I'll be cautious about my reservations about this game, so here goes:Uber:-  Decent selection of character races & classes-  Has a glowing-sparkly trail of prettiness that you can choose to show which leads you to your next objective-  Fast sense of progression, your character obtains new skills and abilities regularly which keeps it interesting-  Some ability graphics look really goodMeh-  Physics graphics are cheesy - players run with an odd motion-  Interacting with objects or NPC's can be tedious as you need to 'interact' with F key which can be buggyJust....no-  Very linear when not in town - always a set path-  Early level game mechanics are highly favourable to the player (overpowered) and although that can be fun sometimes I found it made the beginning of the game bat-turd boring. Overall it seems to be trying to follow the game play mechanics of World of Warcraft but without the cartoon graphics.  As an avid Dungeons & Dragon's fan I was hoping for more with character creation but I appreciate how it can become daunting if over complicated.Overall it's a decent free to play game but I wouldn't spend money on it.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I was having a decent time at this MMORPG lite.  It was kind of simple and easy to get into.  The missions progressed rather easily and there is a lot of player created content that has passably playable dialogue.  But after I hit about level 35 or so, the difficulty of the mission progression seemed to stop suddenly and required me to start grinding out earlier quests or find parties.There were also a lot of minor issues like the pathing that guides a person around quests, tiny text errors here and there, and occassional problems with major party quests not updating as having been completed.  I could overlook these things but it did seem to lack a lot of polish, although in most respects very functional.Unfortunately this ended one day when after an update the game just failed to launch.  I tried repairing it through the ingame repair system, I tried uninstalling and reinstalling, and then I even tried a work-around I needed to do for Dota 2 which I had the same problem with once.  None of it worked and I can no longer play this game even though I had wanted to.  I just tried again after a few months and the problem still persists.  Oh well!  It's F2P anyway.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												I have a love for DnD games. I really have given this game a fair play. Over 400 hours of gameplay on the clock. Which I spent in part with guild mates, friends, and by myself.The game boasts great combat and exciting DnD stuffs to tingle your taste buds. For long time fans and newcomers alike.Each class feels unique and has its own challenges and paths to grow upon. Making you feel more epic with each ability you gain or master. The game is quick to award your heroic deeds with exciting loot and treasure, making it a fast to "grind" and a fun time with friends or guild mates. The graphics do look quite good for a F2P, and you never have to be stuck with one setting for a long period of time.There are so many great looking locations to feast your eyes on. Also a wonderful array of foes to slay! There is a great amount of fan service from the depths of the dungeons and beyond.There is also a wonderful custom map/ adventure maker! Allowing player generated content like I’ve never seen before in a MMO! You can take on the collective imagination of DnD fans from generations old and new. An outstanding feature and worthy of a look.But this game has a horrible underbelly, a dark one. I regret to inform you that it is rotten to its core as a social experience.It has fallen to the same fate of many F2P games. In the most typical and harmful ways.Complete with gold buying/selling, spam from bots, power hungry players with no social graces, and a terrible micro transaction system that hungers for your cash long after you have fed it. Boasting “sales” and “bonus packages”. Some of which are cringe worthy.  I have listed some of these grievances below. If you want to skip down to my final thoughts please do.There is a serious problem with the power balance due to an inflated economy system and broken auction house feature. Making it difficult to match your peers in PVP, gain knowledge in-game of items and their uses, and keep current in dungeon runs without the help of the richest guilds or deepest wallet. Crafting in the Neverwinter also costs you laughable wait times and pitiful returns. The pay components costing too much and the in game alternative being "buying gold" for powerful gems and enchantments. Leaving a huge gap between the player base.The micro transaction system has a list of sins which can go on for miles. For starters, you have to spend increments of money for a simple purchase, locking you into owning in game money and pitching it for items. You have to pay separate fees for every aspect of this game. Most of which is per-character. From expanding your bank/ inventory per character. To buying keys for random chance pots. My favorite being the respect token for changing your character abilities/ feats. It must be purchased every time you want to change your character’s play style. It is not unlocked, but purchased every time for any given character. Playing this game for free is very possible. But a long term investment in the Neverwinter can cost you the price 2-6 new titles or pay-to-play services with far better customer service.And formost..The game has attracted the typical internet fare, meaning you will spend more then enough social time blocking or muting your fellow gamers to get some peace from trash talk.  The community at large doesn’t respect itself, and you will be hard pressed to not to run into these types on a daily basis. Please, avoid this game if you are looking for a un-invasive F2P social game.  There are a few people making this game worth playing society wise. For every few guilds making the game open and fun for anyone. There are dozens of hateful players waiting for you.If this game was sub-based, or a standalone title, I would suggest to everyone I know!As a F2P. It’s a good thing gone sour.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Like this game a lot, it's fairly easy to learn and the animations are really nice. Graphics are also great, but I tone mine down some due to lag. When there's over 30 players in an area it can get really bad. Thankfully there's the option to move to another channel with less players.The fighting is both mouse and select keys, but you can customize your set up so those that wish to can. There's an auction house, there's dungeons and you can upgrade your gear and give your companions upgrades too. There are events that offer extra bonuses and something to do besides quests, dungeons and pvp areas.There are new expansions and new race or even new class options, currently there is a new expansion coming soon. There is a new class that will be coming soon. Not sure if there's room for another race at the moment, but one never knows.Customizing a character avatar is really nice and there's even an area under History where you can enter a bio about the character. There's a bank and email system, mounts and there's even player created dungeons/instances that you can play. After a certain level, you can even try a go at making your own.This game offers a lot of ways to play and things to do. I think it's well worth it for a free 2 play game. Yes there is a store, but it isn't required to buy anything to have fun playing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Pros :1. Hours of entertaining gameplay!2. Hundreds of quests so you never get bored!3. A ton of different adventure zones to travel to and from.4. A quest maker called The Foundry to share, and make your own quests!5. Fun dungeons and good loot at the end!6. A good party/buddy system to quest and adventure with new friends you meet ingame!7. The ablility to dye your characters clothing! (Small feature but good!)8. Thousands of gear to find in dungeouns, quests, and the campaign!9. Mounts to ride for faster travel!10. 8 different classes as of now and another coming soon!11. Multiple races and vast customizing of your character!Cons :1. 2/3 of the things in the Pros list are bought with real world currency for Zen. (the ingame currency)2. Needs a fairly good pc. 3. One of the races is locked as DLC.4. Playing multiple hours at a time makes your butt hurt from your chair. It makes you have to take breaks. What a horrible game!Overall I would highly reccomend this game. As it says it is a D&D style game with upgradable attributes and skills. Other games like TERA lack in this department. I havent found an MMORPG that ive liked this much in a while, Great for friends to play or just solo. GO PLAY IT.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												EDIT: They have already brought back 4 of the older dungeons, and a lot of new content with the latest expansion "The Maze Engine."Quite a decent mmorpg, faithful to the Dungeons and Dragons universe. Action based combat, standard leveling system that is a bit tweaked to match the dungeons and dragons feat and stat system, and not really pay to win, as some people have suggested. You can gather gear without paying anything, and you can also buy Zen, the currency that you need to pay real money for, with actual in game cyrrency (Astral Diamonds), although it is quite expensive. My only issue with the game so far (I am a lvl 60 guardian fighter) is that they removed many of the older dungeons in order to revamp them to match the higher levels, and many storylines fall flat just before you face the final boss, because there is no dungeon to go into. However, they have already started bringing some of them back, so this issue should be resolved in the near future.Other than that, I am having a lot of fun with it, especially as a person who is an avid DnD player (both dungeon master, and actual player), since I know a lot about the world I am playing in. If you enjoy fantasy, and an action based combat, give it a shot. After all, it is free :)

Take my actual game time, remove about 30 hours and that's how much I actually played because the launcher is utter cancer. Second the game is horribly optimized, I have to play something that looks pretty much like morrowwind style graphics yet it still has almost no frame and my pc is really not that bad because I play games that look tons better but run tons better too. You can't really do all that much without spending either totally insane ammounts of time playing or spending money. You are limited to 2 characters unless you buy more slots or spend hours upon hours to get enough stuff to sell and then convert the diamonds into zen etc etc bla bla... I really gave this game my everything and no matter how much I wanted to love this game I just couldn't because there were way too many issues. Gameplay is awesome and so is the story and overall lore and I honestly love these but like I said just way too many issues for me to recommend this game to anyone. If you've got a beast of a pc with way too much time and/or money on your hands, pick the game up and enjoy otherwise goodluck actually playing.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												After playing roughly 30 hours, I can say the game wouldn't be for me, and I personally don't recommend it. My reasoning is that it gets unbelievably repetitive, its like you are copying what you did every time, just fighting or managing something that is a different shape or color. If anything, I want a game that is creative, stands out, keeps interesting, etc. This game just didn't have those qualities. And leveling up is such a pain at some times, as stated before, its very repetitive, and it gets harder which makes it slower. Overall, it was okay at first, but it lost it's spark early in the game.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Well, this is one of my fav free to play games on Steam, and when I say FREE-TO-PLAY it is free to play. Anyone can say this game requires real money but if you spend some time playing it you can reach a conclusion that if you do enough daily dungeon, skirmish and PvP you will get a lot of Astral diamonds and with those diamonds you can convert to Zen Coins. so yeah. totaly free to play game. I've spent some time now and I've created and deleted a lot of character's and in my opinion they are pretty well made with a lot of awesome combos. In my opinion this game still needs a little of optimization for low end pc's. Oh and one more thing, I requested a GM help because I had my missons bugged and within 1-2min my problem was fixed!!! no joke :DGood game with awesome gameplay, easy to learn and endless fun. Neverwinter is one of the best free to play games on steam right now and you play it!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game was simply "ok" when it came out, After several character nerfs (with the promise of more to come) and the destruction of the ingame economy and the massive mirco-transaction style, this game is bad. period.I cant even say micro-transactions when 1 item can cost you 160 dollars. This game was bought by a foreign company that stripped what they HAD TO, an only what it had to from D&D, so that they can build a simple illusion and then nickel and dime you. (More like 20 and 50 you). They even Charge 200 dollars for the hero of the north pack, this game as a whole isnt worth that, ontop of that you still have to pay for other stuff in the game! Most items of value in this game are bound to your account on pick up or on equip, which means you cant trade it to other players for your mutual benefit, pwe/cryptic wont allow that. Their most recent assualt on player to player trading was to bind all enchanted keys, now its much much harder to trade up for better gear/items. They did this just intime for their lockbox event which you need these keys to open.. if you cant trade for keys guess where you have to go to get them now? Bottom line. If you plan on grinding for your gear and taking the time to learn your class and to understand it, or even giving pwe/cryptic your money in order to get ahead in this game, stop and think about this. They bind the items you own to stifle you, while giving them the edge in market, they nerf your character class after the hard work and effort you poured into it, youll most likely have to respec now, that isnt free btw..With asking prices or 35 50 100 200 bucks for single items, you are given NO SECURITY for your investment.This game is near death, Nothing, no amount of money you pay for it is going to let you keep your character or items once they decide they arent making enough money to keep servers up anymore. After driving away the life force of the game with unfair business costs, in the end they still made money and walk away conteplating what franchise they can hijack and run into the ground next. You? youre out how ever much money you wasted and have NOTHING to show for it.. since ive played first, ive uninstalled multiple times and each time i came back wanting to give this game another chance, based on my love for d&d, but each time ive come back to find a new way cryptic has ruined this game. There are chat bugs/ friendslist bugs note bugs, dungeon delve chest bugs (you arent guranteed your epic chest after epic dungeons anymore) the game constantly crashes and quest bugs. I can understand bugs, relly i get it..but these bugs have been around since i first started playing! how can cryptic program so many more pay walls or item bindings or new items to buy but cant fix bugs.. that shows where their priorities are. 3/10 screw PVE/CRYPTIC and evetyone who even looks like pwe and cryptic for hijacking D&D and ruining it. try it for yourself or read all the other negative reviews.

												I am no stranger to MMO's having played World of Warcraft since Vanilla as well as playing Wildstar and Star Citizen but when I did finally try Neverwinter I was blown away. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												Decided to rewrite my review.. This game has really great graphics.. I have been playing this game for awhile ..I have found  a lot of friendly players in comparisson  to other MMos.. The Down side to this Game  is  the gain of Astro diamonds which is  their true  in game currency ..Gold is  only  used for  potions and few other things.. You need astro diamonds  to buy  stuff on the auction house or purchase  items from  their astrodiamon venders .Recent  update made   it so you can  gain 7, 200 a day from  doing both Dungeons and Skirmishes   you can refine 2,400 Astro Diamonds a day. the prices for  most things in the auction house is  really high..There is always tons of Gold spammers..The great thing about this game your not hindered  from quests you don't get told you must vip in order to get access to quests or  hotbars or other things.. Their Vip offers you  xp Boost,  1 enchanted key .which unlocks a   lockbox that gives you a random item and trade bars not many trade bars but adds up..the key is only 1 character a day on the account your viped..  however each characters get also  gives you a bag that gives 10 identifications scrolls a day and a epic dungeon key.. you gain vip levels   that doesn't lower  when you pay for  Vip (i haven't  varified this fully)  but your Vip  does expire depending on the vip you chose .. .This game is worth a shot.. :))

Posted: January 11, 2015
												-----THIS IS LEGIT PLEASE READ----- So ive played Neverwinter for more than the amount of hours i have on steam because it was originally installed on Arc. ---- THIS IS NOT BAAD OK? -----Even though  Neverwinter got some thumbs down, trash reviews, the game is still amazingly fun to play. Many people say Neverwinter is a f2p (free to pay) game even though it isnt. You can easily get everything you could ever want in this game for absoulutely FREE! You just need some time and effort. Now even if you pay it would make things a LOT easier but just to prove point you can get anything for free. Note: (The extra race that comes in the dlc is a paid race, but its not too big of a deal, shh)---- Pros ----- Class/Races are all unique in its own way, you can customize in depthly your perfect character with 7 classes and 12 races of different variety to the stealhy Trickster Rogue and the brutal Great Weapon Fighter.- Graphics are nice a fluid and feel like you are playing a Dungeons and Dragons game it is suppose to be. Even though some people say the graphics are cartoony, look at the games that are popular like *cough* Borderlands 1/2.- Great community, now this is just opionated, but i think the community for NW is kind and "family" like. For me i am in a guild who always is responsive and always ready to do runs (dungeons) which is hard to come by in soloq.- Leveling... instead of the many hours it takes to grind to get to max level like in most mmo's, in NW you can easily get max level in 2 days non-stop (not like ive expirimented). People say this is bad, but i think it is great because late game is what the majority of NW is about.- Controls, the controls for the game fit your hand perfectly, with only few abilities per slot that you can have. Instead of having the millions of powers, spells, combos that have you hitting every number on your keyboard in NW you can only 8 abilities for quick fluid control. (You can swap out different abilities ofc, if people were confused by that).- Late game, is one of most fun things to do in NW, with the 5 FREE MODS (dlc) that came out just for achieving that perfect toon to have the perfect equipment, stats, and looks that we so desire. Even though the game is born after Dungeons and Dragons, its not all Dungeons. There are many other things to do, pvp, daily quests, foundry (the best), events and also the Action house. I know there is more but i cant name at the top of my head. Now ofc there is dungeons which is a blast to run through with your friends.- ALL OF THE MODULES (DLC) ARE FREE. yup it is.---- Cons ----- Could be more open world... its all divided between different zones.- Nerfs are a little annoying to some classes after mod 5.- Cant think of anything that could be bad other than the amount of time it takes to farm Astral Diamonds to certain expensive items.Its reallly your choice, but i would recomend playing it before you pass it.

												Neverwinter is just like every other MMORPG released. It's amazing how this genre has not seen any innovations for years, but the games keep attracting players by simply changing up the attacks, character models and dialogue.Walk, walk, talk to NPC, go fetch stuff, walk, walk, talk to NPC, go kill stuff, walk, walk.So boring. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												People class this game as "Pay to win", I just don't understand how you can think that. Every item which can be obtained via methods of real currency can also be obtained in the game. Some people think that the PVP is just a battle of "who has spent the most money on their gear" and yeah, that's how most games work guys. With your three encounters, two dailys and passives, everyone is very equally matched and the only thing which makes one player stronger from another is the gear. Yes, skill and teamwork do take a part but at the end of the day. Work hard, earn gear, rule Neverwinter, or, Spend real money, buy gear, rule Neverwinter.Either way, this game is a incredible freebie and is well worth a play!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The game is nice, but the Foundry is what shines the most with the ability to play virtual Dungeon Master...  And since you can pretty well customize your social channel tabs, the annoying elements can be silenced efficiently to focus on your game style (even to the point of having the impression of NOT playing just another MMO at all... a blessing for the anti-socially enclined and generic grumpy old dudes just trying to play dungeons & dragons in friggin' peace)... The controls are fairly standard if you've played other games of the genre (Everquest, Diablo & Sacred series) and the learning curve is forgiving enough at the early stages, not so much later-on but that's just spicing it up. Would have preferred a more classical class system but I guess real challenges AD&D died after 2nd edition, when kids were too scared of playing with THAC0 rules and began having thieves throwing magic missiles :P But the game itself is still fun, in video game format.
