content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Neverwinter is a great MMORPG and you can easily spend hours apon hours on this game.Yes there are some in-game purchases but this game is surely not a pay to win game i mean there are some aspects of what you can buy with real money and just have slighty better equitment then others but wont give you a huge advantage on PvP and especially PvE.There are many ways to dodge these payment methods but would just take a little more longer time, which im sure you have. But i would say it is tottally worth paying for a couple of items in game and it doesn't bug me one bit :)The Items you would probs pay for is a faster Mount, Champion (Follower) and maybe a 10x (bundle/deal) of lockbox keys.Which would probs cost you 25-30$ I highly recommend this game as the gameplay is awesome and there are hours of content in game.I would also recommend is grabbing a couple of friends the level with each other and once you guys reach the max (Level 60) you guys could go on Dungeons, Domonation PvP, Skermishes and Foundry quests (Quests that are made by players them selvs.)Dont just take my word for it and go and give it a try :) Thanks for reading this :DAlso come check out my gaming channel :)http://www.youtube.com/user/turtl3vg

												I've retaken this game after a short experience in single player to try it in multyplayer. Besides the game mechanics, that I judge innovative and different from the usual MMO system, this game manages to give a clear presentation of the forgotten realms to those who still don't know them, with lore items, character's personalization and short but good dialogues. So, if you want a "all leveling and raidin" experience, this is still a good option but I'll suggest other wow copies. If you want to discover or, like me, meet again the Forgotten Realms and enjoy the D&D style, go ahead and try itPS: really light requirements, very accessible

												Neverwinter was able to hold my interest to a lasting degree, something that no other MMO has. Between the rich lore and the dynamic, quick combat system, it is much more accessible and interesting than, say, WoW. The freemium status doesn't hurt either, and the classes are fun and varied, with regular updates.That said, it is more interesting to play when you have a buddy to watch your back and level up with you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Downloaded the game 3 days ago, and now I have 30+ hours of playtime on Neverwinter. It's THAT addictive.The game is great! Lots of people, a good questing system, etc. Many agree that this game is amazing, but there are some cons despite what the community and players tell you. Based on what I have found on my 30 hours of gameplay, let me show you my pros/cons.Important Notes:-This game is not P2W like many say, you can go along fine playing for free, just steer clear of the PvP arena, the P2W players will be there.-Game is in english...Pros:-Great questing system, and trackfinder.-Combat is great!-Lots of people always online, you'll probably never go into an instance and find that you're the only one there.-Lots of content-Amazing graphics for a free game, can lower/higher at will.-Engaging.-Can spend HOURS on this game and not get bored.-Many dungeons, can spend hours playing with friends in a dungeon and have a great time there.-There's a bit of secret bosses, places, etc you can find in a dungeon.Cons:-You can only get 1 basic mount, then you'd have to either wait till an event comes or buy it with zen.-Astral Diamonds --> Zen is at a very low exchange rate.-Lots of stuff in the game, the AD and Zen are overpriced.-Mods speak in a different language than english. (For all you englishmen)-The damn dropboxes get annoying, you get the same thingo over and over again, and you can't open it without zen.Summary:The game's great for first-time RPG players to try and get a taste of things, and you could really have fun in this game. But to achieve true potential of this game, you'd need to grab a few bucks out of your wallet to really make your character stand a chance in those PvP arenas. Note:I hope you found this guide useful, enjoy your stay in NeverWinter!

number of helpful: 35 of 70 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												NeverWinter is the best F2P-from-the-start MMO to date. By that I mean, disregarding MMOs that started P2P and then made the switch to F2P (eg. LOTRO, RIFT, et al.).There's a lot of content without ever having to drop a dime, not just in the core game itself, but because of the hundreds of player-made modules - some of which are quite good. Unlike PoE, which has aesthetic-only micro-transactions, NW does have boosts and gear you can buy, but all of it can be bought with in-game money (a lot, of course), and none of it is P2W.The game may not be for everyone because the combat feels different than your typical MMO (more like a third-person action-adventure game), but I quite liked it.PS. This is NOTHING like NWN or NWN2.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												Ok, here's the serious answer. You can spend time or money to get more powerful.. Sorry for the crappy crayon drawing and lame graph, but I had to make due in a pinch. Power gains are rapid and easy for small investments of time/money. However, the way the game works, it becomes increasingly expensive in terms of time or money to increase your power, to the point where it might take days or weeks (or supposedly hundreds of dollars) to increase your power a very, very, very small amount...like less than 1%.Thus at a high level, a character might have exponetially more hours (or money) invested in it, but a very, very small actually difference in power (5-10%). For some people, this is apparently a huge deal. Particularly in PvP there are some people who simply do not possess the skills or reflexes to overcome a 5% difference in gear. For others who are very skilled or practiced, that differences is far outweighed by said skills.However, you're going to see the typical "OMG IT COSTS LIKE THOUSANDS OF DOLLAHS TO BIS" stuff when this question gets asked. And the answer is, yes, if you want to level to 60 and instantly have the best EVERYTHING, the market price is probably close to $2000. But if you're willing to put even just a small amount of time into the game, that price drops dramatically...zero for some people.

												Laggy, buggy, grindy as hell of course like in all go kill X mmos, dungeons are ridiculously difficult and thats totally OK with me... problem starts with the rewards... they absolutely not worth the hassle you can just skip all dungeons in the game and lvl right to the top while not doing a single one and you'll be absolutely fine...This game of course, as is the case with all mmos with more or less shiny graphics, will interest all the usual kiddie passengers of hype trains, but not mmo veterans like me and perhaps you if you got at least 10 years of mmo experience - walk right past this one, nothing for you here, this game will make you fall a sleep out of boredom.More details:1. I haven't figured an efficient way of making astral diamonds except doing those dailies that grant you 1-5k per quest then cooldown for 4++ hours yet they ask you to pay 300k of them just so you can upgrade ur companion and allow him/her to lvl up from 15 to 20... i shudder to think how much it will ask you to pay for the upgrade from lvl 20 and up....2. Reward box that you open as you level up drops only absolutely worthless stuff, i dunno why its even there... probably to make Perfect World Entertainment look charitable.3. Crafting is a total laugh not only not worth the hassle but the mats are difficult to procure as well unless of course you open your pockets... and it works in a way made for EMPERORS of LAZY, cause absolutely everything is automated.. you only need to push button and forget it for a few hours.4. Combat dull as hell, basically you just chop mobs by using 3 skills and left mouse button - thats it. (yes, for real).------------------------------------------------------------------Sigh~ when will they start to make actually FUN mmorpgs.... makes me want to be born in 80's againAh right almost forgot... in case you were lured here by Neverwinter Nights the rpg made by bioware, don't be deceived, this game has NOTHING i repeat, NOTHING of what made the rpg Neverwinter Nights fun, nothing whatsoever.The mmorpg version of Neverwinter is a failure that will quite possibly kill-out any further sequels to the original Neverwinter Nights the rpg... a most grave loss for me because they rarely make such amazing rpg's these days.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I really enjoy this game.  It's got a combat system that I really haven't seen before, as well an interesting story.  Let's be Frank though.  I play on Tabletop, so when my friend said DnD Rpg I had to check it out.  The game is very enjoyable, and has plenty of hours of opportunity, but it's entirely Pay to Win.  Sure you can purchase the in game Real world currency for Astral Diamonds (an in game currency) but the exchange rate is insane.  Meaning like most other MMO, those who pay end up being those that rule the Events or Pvp.  Currently the best enchants and gear are nearly impossible to get without using real world money.  The gameplay is fun, linking all the quests together with an introductory cutscene, it makes for both excellent story, and beautiful graphics.  That being said, people need to remember the game isn't  that old.  As the second Module just came bringing the class total up to 6, there isn't all that much varity for compisitions. The leveling curve isn't anywhere near as steep as other games, meaning you can get a character to the current level cap of 60 in just a few days, which may leave you bored feeling like there is nothing left to do but spam those final high level missions for loot.  Gameplay is fairly simple.  It's enjoyable and not at all hard to get the hang of.  The skill tree can be somewhat overwhelming at first, and it may be worth your interest to get a respec after you've gotten to the level cap just so that your first time through you can learn what all your skills do and play with different combinations. The compainion system is a great idea, allowing players to have a Cleric follower heal them if they're squishy, or a Striker doing damage if they're a tank.  But the sheer number of resources it takes to level the 5 basic ones up past level 15 means they quickly fall out in usefulness.The foundry system is neat as it allows players to make and share their own quests and stories in game.  Just a neat thing I think.New players who join now wont be jumping into a game with everybody at the level cap.  There is plenty of people at all levels, so finding a group to play with isn't that hard.

content:
Posted: March 19
												IGNORE EVERYONE WHO HATES AND SAYS THIS IS PAY TO WIN!!!!!   THIS GAME IS COMPLETELY F2P!!!!!The currency focus is on Astral Diamond to Zen conversionAD Farming is actually really fun, and once you hit the lvl 60-70 mark is a way to get the gear you're looking for anyway.  The campaigns for lvl 70 that give you daily repeatables actually help with their own individual facet of the game throughout.  For examples, one campaign focuses on armor, another is geared towards artifacts and refining, one has an angle towards a specific in game profession, but the boons and gear you get from each "grindy campaign" help in the PvP matches so that you DON'T have to spend any real money to get great, OP, gear.  By doing skirmishes and dungeons daily you can earn Astral Diamonds.  You can also earn them from selling items in the Auction House.  You can then convert the AD to Zen and "spend real money" in the game without actually spending a penny.  That's where it can seem a little grindy to have to farm AD's daily, but if you have the help of a guild/stronghold behind you, I can almost guarantee that you will find some people to help you get that done!  Then it brings up the point of not just Domination style PvP but you can have stronghold vs. stronghold in raids and sieges!!!  The stronghold idea has only further expanded the playability of the game.  I LOVE this game and would (and have) recommended it to everyone I know!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Having logged a significant amount of time and after finally taking a serious interest in this game I think it is time for a review. Why you should play NW: (i.e. Is it worth the time)If you have enjoyed playing MMOS in the past (wow,Tera,vindictus, etc..) you should try NW and if your new to MMOS it's a great starting point. For grizzled MMO vets it is a nice refresher with great combat, a wide array of skills and powers, and an economy that is pretty stable (for now). The PvE is interesting and a fun thing to run through, it's got great visuals and a large amount of characters. PvP is also present in a big way. The que system is well organized and there is even ranked play. There are also whole different play styles based on pvp (different armor to use, powers, feats, items, etc). The game itself has great visuals and any graphics hungry max setting fps PC behemoth computer builders have a chance to go nuts graphics wise. (Don't worry it also runs on toasters). End game content ramps up the PvE and PvP in a big way with campaigns and artifacts so tons of play value after basic lvling campaign is done. Also like all MMOS you got your guilds and they have events and it's all hunky dory (if you can't tell I tend to solo play).If you are new to MMOS NW is great because it in a sense is simple. It guides you in the beginning better than any MMO I have seen. The combat is quick to grasp but still fun and interesting. Figuring out your play style/kit you use comes easily as you settle into your character.Problems with Neverwinter.Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥we got somethings to talk about: (keep in mind despite all this I still love/am addicted to NW)First and foremost: this game in a significant manner is pay to win. Endgame PVP is ruined by people that can decimate you due to there incredibly overpowered kits. Seeing a guy that has almost 3x the gear score you have in the same pvp match as you leaves some very lasting effects on my opinion of pvp. Anyway back to the pay system. I recommend that you invest at least a little cash in this game as a jumping off point once you reach lvl 70 just because you won't last a second in pvp if you don't. I wish there was no pay system and we could just upfront pay for Neverwinter so the title Free To Play wasn't slapped on it. Just invest a little on enchantments. And a mount and refining and more refining and even more refining (you get the point) The refining system: ok so in this game there are artifacts that you have to charge with refining points to make them better (also enchantments to charge but eh ♥♥♥♥ that). Currently the final ranks of artifacts vary (legendary/mythic) to get to legendary takes waaaayyyyyyyy to many refining points so don't even get me started on mythic. This system in principle is good in practice but holy ♥♥♥♥ it takes to long. Cryptic, listen, do everyone a solid and make refining less of a grind and give us some time left on our lives. Seeing people run around with all mythic gear makes me seriously question the state of their bank account or the state of their social life( no offense no lifers). I can't imagine the time it would take to do that. Back to PVP: ok so pvp as a game type is great. Capture the points on a 5 on 5 match, fun, simple, organized BUT!!!! BUTT!!!!!!!!! It is so unbalanced. Once in a millennia do I find a game where it is a hard fought good game between two relatively even teams that comes down to a last push or last second play. Almost always there is a clear winner from the beginning. This is always attributed to mismatched gear scores. I should not be a guy with a gear score of 2,600 facing a guy with a GS of 4,500 (measured as of 2/16/16, measuring of gear scores has changed before). Fix this please. Organize it by rank or gear score or whatever, even if it takes longer to que it will be worth it.  Alone vs Party play: if I can recommend anything to newcomers is find a friend early on. I choose to play solo (my choice can't blame the game) but it is hard. Forget dungeon delving alone it can't be done (except you 4.5k GS guy) also things can get a little grindy sometimes and it is nice to have a friend during this time. Also 2 heads are better than 1, NW offers a lot especially lvl 60 and up. Having a friend to help figure things out with will benefit you in many ways. This is less a criticism and more a helpful recommendation. Find a friend or find a guild do it early or be prepared you brave soul.FINAL NOTE:Despite these minor problems ( the few lines of code Satan himself added) I still love NW. Why I don't entirely know. Maybe because I have a serious addiction to a game that can suck money like Gaben during a steam sale or maybe it is a new breath of fresh air in the MMO genre with a nice combat system a wide array of play styles and classes and a constantly updated and changing world with a dedicated dev team. If anything proves that I like this game it is the 330+ hours I have spent on it. Try it, love it for the gameplay and hate it for the pay system but don't miss it.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												So now I'm 20 hours into the game. I'm level 34 (almost half-way to the level 70 cap) And most of the 20 hours I've played the game for have consisted largely of the same thing; Talking to someone, killing a bunch of things, interacting with some sparkly object and returning to the same person to repeat the pattern until they tell me to go to se someone else.Repetitive as that sounds, I've really enjoyed it! I'm aware that there are more things to do in the game, like profesions and dungeons, but those three things are about it. and all I care to know about the main story is that it involves some necromancer or something like that.I've also heard that the game contains things called "Campaigns", buit I'm going to assume that I'm too low-level for them as I havent found a way to access them.I've found that the loot-drops are quite good... I regularly fing myself changing around my gear and enchantments, unlike other loot-based games where I will usually end up sticking with the same lucky drop for many many hjours before I find somethiong better.And I've always hated targeted combat in MMOs (Just one of the reasons runescape sucks)... The combat in this game feels fluid and engaging. You really feel like your personal skill level effects the outcome of the battle.Overall:Story: 6/10Gameplay: 8/10Voice-acting: 4/10 (There are some truly horrible attempts at regional accents scattered here-and there)Content: 8/10Maps: 9/10 (Big and Varied, for the most part)Yep... This game cured all my cravings after bninge-watching SAO in a day!

content:
Posted: March 9
												Been searching for MMORPGs lately, and I stumble upon this among many other MMORPGs.Neverwinter is a MMORPG game set in typical D&D setting. Neverwinter tells you a story about a kingdom which is now a shadow of its former self. The remain of the city of Neverwinter was only Protector's Enclave, which even was built recently by the king Neverember in order to preserve the fallen Neverwinter. Other parts of the city has either overrun by orcs, rebel, and even undead and demons. There's The Foundry, which is basically quest maker. You can make your own quest here, and other players can play and rate it.The main plus for this game is the simplicity and action. Unlike some MMORPG of its time, Neverwinter offer some different playtype for you to play and some skills available at your disposal. The Foundry is quite an interesting aspect of the game. However, what lacks in Neverwinter is open-world. This game lets you feel the 90% of the game after you reached level 70. Leveling up is easy as well.TL;DRThis is a great game to play solo, but if you like more open world game, this game might not suit you. 8/10

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												This game may be good for people who want a more casual MMO experience. If you are bothered by the "Go here and Kill Y number of X" this game has very few of those. In the beginning there aren't that many. The quests are interesting for the most part.Around level 30 there's a little bit more of the lame quests, but doing these lame quests is thank god not your only option. The skirmishes are a lot of fun. They are small party dungeon runs. Those are a LOT of fun.THE best thing this game has to offer is the Foundry (user created quests and dungeons). The Foundry quests are simply awesome. They are almost as good as if they were taken out of a single player RPG like Dragon Age. There was a Game of Thrones themed one, where I had to battle alongside Jon Snow. There was also one where you became an evil character, became the dungeon overlord, gathered minions and killed the heroes.There are also episodic Foundry quests, which are constantly updated by the kind user. Doing all the episodes can last several days. 1 episode is usually 30 mins long and they are ideal for doing daily foundry quests. That way you always get just a little bit further with the quest's own story.So the leveling up part is good and a lot more fun than in other MMOs (e.g. 1st 20 levels of wow are boring. here they are fun). Once you hit level 60, you will still have more campaigns to do, which came with the modules (expansions) and reach level 70. There's a lot to do, it looks like you won't get bored of those for several hundreds of hours.HOWEVER, the end-game sucks big-time. Once you are done with all the campaigns, it's not really worth playing it anymore, unless you are planning on investing real money. Sure you can get the shiny mounts by farming too, but that requires way too much grind. To get the same items, you have to grind for several weeks intensively every day (6+ hours/day).But you won't get there until you spent like 100+ hours with the game, which are actually fun.+ new expansions are always around the corner, which give you more campaign missions and new areas to explore, new dungeons, skirmishes, etc. All in all, I think 100+ hours of fun is worth downloading, I think. Then you can still do the insane amount of Foundry missions available. OR create some yourself for some little sandboxing and become the Dungeon Master yourself!Also, PVP sucks. It just sucks, nothing more to say about it.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												So...well let me kep it short for you (or not, idk yet) - the game runs like trying to kick barefoot a lubed brick up a slippery slope, regardless of what machine you have. Gameplay wise -the idea isn't that bad, but the game is not only badly optimised but it also has lag issues, again regardless of your your internet, which makes the combat pretty much screwed (mobs hit you even before they raise their swords, so dodging is practically pointless in most cases). Even if you are willing to overlook such things (for some weird reason, you poor lonely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥), the game gets repetitive very, very soon (Like most games associated in any way with PW). You would be stuck doing daily quests and going in the same instances over and over, and over, and over. Grinding FTW... is I guess what the devs thought.The game also wants you to pay for even small things that you shouldn't (if you want more than 2 character slots, and etc.) and to top it off everything is overpriced (at the time I played there was also a race behind a stupidly high paywall).The saving grace of the game is probably the eastetics, but they can only work on you for a time. Don't waste you time on it, you would only be disappointed as you realise how much better the game could have been, but sadly will probably never be.

												I've been playing NW for a while now and so far I'm really enjoying it. It seems really well made and I'm having fun exploring and completing the quests. The devs do a pretty good job of connecting with the players as well. I've been able to watch a couple of their twitch streams and like that they give out a bunch of prizes and also in-game content just for joining in.I think this game is definetly better in a party, so go find (or make) a friend or two!
